description: Instagram tweaks its algorithm after employees of the company made complaints, accusing the platform of hiding pro-Palestinian content

title: (Untitled)
description: Meta, Facebook's parent company, partners with Canadian news publishers on its 'News Innovation Test', a new initiative which will pay participating publishers for the ability to link to additional news stories not already posted on Facebook

title: (Untitled)
description: Rumble secures investments from J.D. Vance's Narya Capital, Peter Thiel, and Colt Ventures. This funding will help Rumble launch new cloud services and enhance its platform. With monthly viewership skyrocketing from 1.6 million to 31 million in a year, the investment bolsters Rumble's ability to build on its rapid growth and expand its infrastructure

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook loses its appeal of a court ruling to suspend its ability to send information about European users to U.S. computer servers. The ruling sets a precedent for restrictions on the company's data flow

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter announces six acquisition deals in 2021, the most since 2015, as the company aims to accelerate its release of new products

title: (Untitled)
description: YouTube announces a $100M fund to reward the top performing YouTube Shorts creators over the course of 2021 and 2022

title: (Untitled)
description: Wired Magazine reports that Rumble's recommendation algorithms direct viewers towards misinformation and extremist content. Researchers find that the platform amplifies conspiracy theories and falsehoods, with a study showing Rumble's algorithms frequently recommending videos containing misinformation. Despite these findings, Rumble defends its practices, claiming it promotes free speech and diverse viewpoints

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook launches a new feature which will alert users against sharing articles they haven't read. If a user attempts to share a news article link they haven't opened, the new feature will show a prompt encouraging users to open it and read it, "before sharing it with others"

title: (Untitled)
description: News Corp, the parent company of a number of a Australian media outlets, formalises deals with Google and Facebook for financial compensation in return for the use of their articles on the platform

title: (Untitled)
description: Substack launches its new feature called "Sections," which will allow writers to set up and manage multiple newsletters or podcasts within one main publication

title: (Untitled)
description: YouTube spends $7 million to set up two new programs that are designed to help journalists build followings on the platform

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter agrees to acquire Scroll, a platform that allows users to read articles without ads while still generating "more revenue" for publishers who work with the platform. Twitter plans to include Scroll as part of a subscription offering

title: (Untitled)
description: The Facebook Oversight Board announces it has come to a decision in its review of Donald Trump's removal from the platform

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter launches a national advertising and social media campaign to boost local news, urging the platform's users to follow local journalists

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook launches its new platform intended to be used by local independent journalists. The company also commits $5 million to supporting local journalists in the U.S., as part of the launch

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook announces that it will hide the hashtag '#ResignModi' because “some content in those posts goes against our Community Standards.” The hashtag gained popularity as dissent grows against India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi over his handling of the country's COVID-19 crisis

title: (Untitled)
description: Tow Center: "Are Google and Facebook really the future of journalism? New Policies risk making it so"

title: (Untitled)
description: The publishers The Guardian declines to use Google's cookieless tracking and ad targeting method, FLoC, over concerns about privacy and discriminatory categorization of users. The New York Times and other publishers remain open to testing the controversial tech

title: (Untitled)
description: A Brazilian court has ordered a temporary suspension of the encrypted messaging app Telegram until it shares information on extremist and neo-Nazi groups. The court also instituted a non-compliance fine that increases by one million reais per day. The federal police requested the suspension after Telegram failed to comply with a previous court order to hand over data about two neo-Nazi groups accused of inciting violence, prompting telecommunications firms to suspend access to the app

title: (Untitled)
description: News publishers curious hold off on joining social audio app Clubhouse, preferring to wait until Twitter and Facebook launch alternatives

title: (Untitled)
description: Daily Mail's owner, DMG Media, sues Google, alleging that the company's monopoly over the digital ad space market means newspapers see little of the revenue their content produces

title: (Untitled)
description: Discord ends talks to sell itself to Microsoft or other companies

title: (Untitled)
description: Apple agrees to let a new version of Parler back onto the App Store, citing the platform's improved content moderation

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook releases a suite of new audio products in an attempt to challenge Clubhouse as the leading audio networking platform

title: (Untitled)
description: Florida Governor Ron DeSantis joins Rumble. In a press release, Rumble welcomes him to the platform and CEO Chris Pavloski applauds DeSantis as "a longtime proponent of free speech" who "has been at the forefront of the effort to demonopolize Big Tech"

title: (Untitled)
description: Substack offers to pay independent writers to write about local news

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook allows a network of fake accounts to artificially inflate the popularity of an MP from India’s ruling Bharatiya Janata party, for months after being alerted to the problem

title: (Untitled)
description: The Guardian reveals that Facebook has allowed major abuses of its platform in poor, small and non-western countries by world leaders in order to prioritize addressing abuses that attract media attention or affect the U.S. and other wealthy countries. The platform frequently allows world leaders and politicians to deceive the public or harass opponents, despite being alerted to evidence of the wrongdoing, says The Guardian

title: (Untitled)
description: Procter & Gamble Co., one of the world's largest ad buyers, works with a Chinese trade group to sidestep Apple's new privacy rules as a way to gather data for targeted ads, as reported by the Wall Street Journal

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitch will now ban users who harass members of its community, even when that harassment takes place off Twitch

title: (Untitled)
description: Spotify continues to remove episodes of the Joe Rogan Experience Podcast, bringing the total to 42 episodes deleted. The platform offered no explanation as to why the shows were removed

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook fails to pay video creators thousands of dollars in ad revenue due to what the company labels a "technical issue"

title: (Untitled)
description: Google makes an initial €25 million contribution to the European Media and Information Fund to support media literacy in the continent

title: (Untitled)
description: Discord introduces a Clubhouse-like feature that lets people easily broadcast live audio conversations to a room full of virtual listeners

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook rolls out a new feature that will let users control more of what they see and customize their 'News Feed, ' instead of relying on algorithms

title: (Untitled)
description: LinkedIn is working on an audio networking feature to compete with Clubhouse

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook pledges $8 million in funding to support news publishing in Canada. The pledge comes while the company faces scrutiny over its decision to remove news from its platform in Australia and Canada pushes for similar legislation

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey's first tweet sold for $2.9 million on Sunday. The buyer said it's the Mona Lisa of tweets

title: (Untitled)
description: Eight European publishers are selected for Google News Initiative's 'Subscriptions Lab', which is designed to strengthen and accelerate growth of media outlets' subscription businesses and help publishers deliver customised plans to users. The eight-month program is being run in partnership with FT Strategies and the International News Media Association

title: (Untitled)
description: The Daily Mail's publisher, DMG Media, rejects Google's publishing deal because the platform's proposal does not offer enough money and its terms are too restrictive

title: (Untitled)
description: Telegram raises over $1 billion in debt financing with Mubadala Investment Company, a sovereign wealth fund based in Abu Dhabi, being a key investor

title: (Untitled)
description: Discord is in talks with Discord to acquire the chat platform for more than $10 billion

title: (Untitled)
description: U.S. Justice Department sues Apple for monopolizing smartphone markets, asserting that the company's "broad-based," exclusionary conduct makes it harder for Americans to switch smartphones, undermines innovation for apps, products, and services, and imposes extraordinary costs on developers, businesses and consumers

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter plans to reassess how it deals with content moderation on world leaders, and is crowdsourcing the answer. The platform hopes to come to a conclusion as to whether world leaders should be subject to the same policies as any other Twitter user

title: (Untitled)
description: The Wall Street Journal investigates how COVID-19 further emboldened Google, Facebook and Amazon's triopoly over the digital advertising market

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook plans to roll out an Instagram app that can be used by children under the age of 13, Buzzfeed News reports. The new platform will use more specific content moderation guidelines

title: (Untitled)
description: Google awards $3 million to news organizations testing new ways to fight misinformation around COVID-19, The $3 million will be split across 11 projects, including a hyperlocal digital news site distributing fact-checks to offline Mexicans using “perifoneo” loudspeakers, interactive radio dramas in Senegal and Nigeria, and a partnership with a trap music star in Uruguay

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook's parent company Meta Platforms Inc launches a new platform that aims to support independent writers and expand their reach. The platform will offer monetization and publishing tools for writers, along with insights from the platform

title: (Untitled)
description: Clubhouse launches its 'Creator Accelerator' program, offering support and income for content creators who use the platform

title: (Untitled)
description: How the Journalism Competition Bill would allow publishers in the U.S. to collectively bargain with Facebook and Google

title: (Untitled)
description: Vice Chair of the Texas GOP Cat Parks calls on her party GOP to delete its Gab account after "multiple grassroots Republican activists reached out with concerns" upon finding that "several comments on [the Republican Party of Texas'] posts contained anti-Semitic and racist tropes." Governor Greg Abbott spoke out against Gab as well, saying that "anti-Semitic platforms like Gab have no place in Texas"

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook markets its new Instagram Lite to replace TikTok in India

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter sues Texas attorney general in retaliation for a suit brought against the company after it banned Donald Trump from the platform following the January 6th Capitol riots

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook preps tool comparing publishers’ mobile web revenue to Instant Articles

title: (Untitled)
description: French media company CheckNews terminates its fact-checking partnership with Facebook

title: (Untitled)
description: Gannett will sell ads on Snapchat to local businesses as part of a digital marketing partnership with the platform

title: (Untitled)
description: Google says it will stop selling advertisements based on specific users' browsing history

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook lifts political ad ban imposed after the 2020 presidential election

title: (Untitled)
description: The news aggregator Flipboard expands its local coverage from 60 localities to more than 1,000 cities and towns in the U.S. and Canada

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter announces it will permanently ban users who spread COVID misinformation

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook launches its news product in Germany without an agreement with media company Axel Springer, which publishes the country's most popular daily newspaper, Bild. The media company says it won't participate due to the 'inappropriately low remuneration' offered for journalistic content

title: (Untitled)
description: The Medium Workers Union pauses organizing efforts after it fails to win a simple majority of support in an online vote

title: (Untitled)
description: Gab suffers a significant hack by Distributed Denial of Secrets (DDOSecrets), with a vast amount of data, including passwords and private messages, stolen. The hack, named GabLeaks, was described by DDOSecrets as attempting to "expose the platform's largely right-wing users." The data is to be selectively shared with journalists, social scientists, and researchers. DDoSecrets co-founder Emma Best wrote that that data is "another gold mine of research for people looking at militias, neo-Nazis, the far right, QAnon, and everything surrounding January 6"

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook launches a new app, Bars, which lets users rap over premade beats

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter debuts subscription products to help double revenue by 2023. The company launches "Super Follows," which aims to expand the platform's revenue stream beyond advertising

title: (Untitled)
description: A Bellingcat investigation finds that far-right influencers in Britain use mainstream platforms like YouTube and Twitter to direct followers to lower-moderation platforms and fundraising sites, allowing them to profit from spreading white supremacist conspiracy theories. BitChute, a British video-hosting site, is particularly notable for being rife with racism and hate speech, and it enables influencers to monetize such content despite its defiant stance on moderation. The investigation reveals a widespread practice among these figures to use alt-tech platforms such as Telegram, BitChute, and Gab, which provide havens for unmoderated hate speech and extremist content

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook reverses its ban that it placed on news pages in Australia. The initial ban came amid a dispute over a proposed law that would require Facebook and Google to negotiate fair prices for journalism with Australian media outlets

title: (Untitled)
description: Google plans to lift its political ad ban put in place following Capitol siege

title: (Untitled)
description: Gab briefly goes offline to address a bitcoin scam, with CEO Andrew Torba stating that a security vulnerability in their codebase had been identified and patched

title: (Untitled)
description: News Corp and Google agree to a three-year partnership deal that will see the platform pay for journalism

title: (Untitled)
description: Reddit announces that it removed 6% of content on its platform in 2020

title: (Untitled)
description: Seven West Media becomes the largest Australian news media company to ink a deal with Google to pay for journalism

title: (Untitled)
description: Parler, previously ousted from AWS due over concerns that it advocated violence, is now back online with a new host, SkySilk. However, users will find all previous content erased. Despite claims of improved content moderation, Parler's return is met with skepticism, as the new CEO's Tea Party background suggests a continuation of the platform's hyper partisan stance

title: (Untitled)
description: Using Epik for web hosting services, Parler reopens with restored user accounts and a new interim CEO, Mark Meckler, amid ongoing legal battles and continued absence from Apple and Google app stores. The platform faces scrutiny after being taken offline in January following the Capitol attack, with concerns over its moderation policies and political affiliations

title: (Untitled)
description: The New Yorker takes a look at the formation and structure of Facebook's new Oversight Board

title: (Untitled)
description: Google agrees to pay $76 million over three years to a group of 121 French news publishers to end a more than year-long copyright spat

title: (Untitled)
description: LinkedIn launches a creator program

title: (Untitled)
description: Medium workers announce they're forming a union with the Communications Workers of America (CWA) Local 9410 and plan to negotiate a contract for members

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook will start showing some of its users less political content

title: (Untitled)
description: Instagram announces tougher consequences for hate speech in direct messages

title: (Untitled)
description: A growing number of new web publishers aren't traditional media companies, but rather corporate marketers setting up blogs and websites to lure potential customers with content

title: (Untitled)
description: Instagram says its algorithm won't promote Reels that have a TikTok watermark

title: (Untitled)
description: Google opens paid-for Australia news platform in drive to undercut Canberra's content payment law. The new platform comes just as the Australian parliament prepared to pass legislation that would oblige platforms like Facebook and Google to pay media outlets to post their content

title: (Untitled)
description: Parler ousts CEO John Matze, with Matze confirming his termination in a memo to staff. The move follows the platform's removal from major app stores and cloud hosting services after the Capitol attack, with lawmakers calling for an FBI investigation into Parler's role in planning the events

title: (Untitled)
description: Instagram editor' is an official title at The Washington Post and the role will play an important part in increasing the newspaper publisher’s subscription business

title: (Untitled)
description: CNN ends its Facebook video deal, and moves its ‘Go There' daily show to its website and mobile app. The move comes as CNN looks to increase viewership and sell advertising on its own platform

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook plans to clamp down on its ‘Groups,’ after under fire for not moderating calls for violence on the platform. The new policy changes will see an "overhaul" of Facebook's previous moderation of 'Groups'

title: (Untitled)
description: The owner of The Charleston Gazette-Mail and other West Virginia news publications files a lawsuit in federal court against Google and Facebook, accusing the companies of profiting from “anticompetitive and monopolistic practices” that have damaged the newspaper business, primarily the monopolization of the digital advertising market

title: (Untitled)
description: Researchers at the Stanford Internet Observatory publish a report on the platform dynamics of Parler. Key findings include that "Parler’s user growth trends show jumps in response to political events in the U.S. and the choice by other platforms to label or remove content from prominent individuals." In one case, the researchers note that Parler's user base doubled in a matter of weeks during the 2020 US presidential election

title: (Untitled)
description: Apple’s new privacy ‘nutrition labels, ’ which indicate to users which apps collect data and which do not, incorrectly marks apps. The company’s plan to make iPhone apps be transparent about the data they take often reports apps which do collect data as downloads which do not

title: (Untitled)
description: Discord reverses its ban of r/WallStreetBets and works to help the team moderate its new server

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook Oversight Board releases its first batch of decisions on five separate cases it adjudicated over, with all but one ruling unanimous. Four overturn Facebook’s original decisions to remove posts, and only one agrees with Facebook

title: (Untitled)
description: Based on research from Community Security Trust (CST), The Times reports on significant amounts of antisemitic content appearing on BitChute. Searches for neutral, Holocaust-related terms revealed numerous videos denying, distorting, or glorifying the Holocaust. Despite Ofcom regulations requiring UK-based video sharing platforms to protect users from harmful content, BitChute continues to host extensive extremist and conspiracy material, prompting CST to report their findings to Ofcom as a critical test case for the regulator's approach to online hate speech.

title: (Untitled)
description: Anatomy of a Facebook Privacy Scandal: How Facebook reacts to privacy scandals on the inside, and why they persist

title: (Untitled)
description: Ekstra Bladet, Denmark's biggest news site, leaves Google Analytics' data framework and takes full control of the entire data flow around its site. The company says the move grants it more data points at a faster rate than it had while using Google's services

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter acquires Revue, a newsletter platform for writers and publishers. The deal marks Twitter's first step into building out long-form content experiences on Twitter, and its first foray into subscription revenue

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook explains how the algorithm works for its newly launched Facebook News

title: (Untitled)
description: After 10 months as a collection of newsletters created via Substack, the team behind the Everything Bundle breaks out on its own with $600,000 in seed funding, its own content and newsletter software built in-house, and a refreshed brand as Every

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook rolls out Facebook News in the U.K.

title: (Untitled)
description: Vice reports that a Telegram user is selling access to a database of phone numbers from Facebook users via an automated bot, despite Facebook previously fixing the vulnerability in 2019. The bot contains real phone numbers of Facebook users, potentially affecting those who linked their numbers to their accounts before August 2019

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter unveils a feature meant to bolster its efforts to combat misinformation and disinformation by tapping users in a fashion similar to Wikipedia to flag potentially misleading tweets

title: (Untitled)
description: Google threatens to make its search engine unavailable in Australia if the government approves legislation that would force tech companies to pay for journalism shared on their platforms.

title: (Untitled)
description: Google seals content payment deal with French news publishers after agreeing to a copyright framework. The deal sees U.S. tech company pay news publishers for content online, a first of its kind deal in Europe

title: (Untitled)
description: The House Oversight Committee is urging the FBI to investigate Parler's role in the Capitol attack, citing instances of users inciting violence against elected officials and organizing protests on the platform. Committee Chair Carolyn Maloney seeks to uncover the ownership and funding of platforms like Parler, highlighting financial support from conservative figures like Robert Mercer. As the FBI receives over 100,000 pieces of digital evidence related to the riot, the committee is opening its own investigation into Parler's involvement

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter locks Chinese Embassy's account in the U.S. following a post the account made defending the Chinese government's policies towards Uighurs. The account is locked after the tweet violated Twitter's ‘dehumanization’ policy

title: (Untitled)
description: The U.S., in a submission to an Australian parliamentary inquiry, attacks Australia's plan to make Google and Facebook pay for news, labeling the bill unreasonable, impractical, and “fundamentally imbalanced.” The U.S. suggests that Australia institutes a "voluntary code," rather than attempting impose a mandatory code of conduct on digital platforms, which would allow for collective bargaining from Australian media outlets to determine payment for displaying news on Facebook and Google

title: (Untitled)
description: Gab experiences a surge in popularity, gaining 2.3 million new users and attracting 55 million visits in a week after Parler, its conservative counterpart, faced removal from the internet after January 6th. Despite criticism for hosting hate-filled content, Gab struggles to maintain smooth operation amid the influx of traffic, while Parler prepares for a potential return online after being removed from Amazon Web Services

title: (Untitled)
description: Apple discusses launching a new subscription service that would charge people to listen to podcasts, as reported by The Information. The move would aim to attract more podcast creators to publish more content exclusively on Apple, with the promise of a monetized platform

title: (Untitled)
description: Axios plans to launch AxiosHQ, a communications platform that will enable businesses to update their employees—including through internal newsletters—in Axios’s "just-the-facts, bullet-point style." The platform will be AI-powered and will aid in internal company communications through clearly structured information presentation

title: (Untitled)
description: Millions are downloading Signal and Telegram amid concerns over content policies and security at big tech companies like Facebook and WhatsApp, which were sparked by the removal of far-right accounts following January 6th and worries about data privacy. Telegram gained 25 million users in three days, while Signal saw 1.3 million downloads in a single day

title: (Untitled)
description: In an open letter, the Anti Defamation League calls for the Department of Justice (DOJ) to investigate Gab's role in the January 6th attack on the capitol. The ADL urges the DOJ to examine whether Gab facilitated or conspired with individuals linked to the attack, emphasizing the accountability of tech platforms in such situations

title: (Untitled)
description: Telegram has taken action against a network of neo-Nazi and white supremacist accounts, removing dozens of channels over concerns of inciting violence, with some boasting more than 10,000 followers. The move follows a "mass-reporting campaign" led by anti-fascist activist Gwen Snyder, prompting extremist channels to blame her and launch a doxxing campaign circulating her home address

title: (Untitled)
description: Snapchat permanently bans Donald Trump's account on Jan. 20, Axios reports, after locking it indefinitely last week following the Capitol siege

title: (Untitled)
description: Google admits to running 'experiments' which remove some media sites from its search results. The tech company's experiments reach "about 1% of users in Australia"

title: (Untitled)
description: The Google News Initiative announces it will give $3 million to news and fact-checking organizations in an effort to combat misinformation about the COVID-19 vaccine. The new commitment brings their total pledged to organizations debunking lies about the pandemic to $11 million

title: (Untitled)
description: Rumble files a lawsuit against Google, accusing it of "unfairly rigging its search algorithm" to favor YouTube. The lawsuit alleges Google manipulates search results to prioritize YouTube and preinstalls the YouTube app on Android devices, maintaining a monopoly in the online video-sharing market, and seeks at least $2 billion in damages

title: (Untitled)
description: YouTube deletes Trump video and suspends new uploads after the channel violates the company's policies against inciting violence

title: (Untitled)
description: Following the January 6th attack on the capitol, a group of hackers exploited the platform's lax security to scrape and archive the site, uploading terabytes of data to the Internet Archive. According to one anonymous hacker, the group downloaded "99%" of public data from Parler with the goal of collecting "incriminating evidence" regarding actors in the January 6th attack. The hack was made possible by the fact that "Parler lacked the most basic security measures that would have prevented the automated scraping of the site's data"

title: (Untitled)
description: Parler files a lawsuit against Amazon after Amazon Web Services (AWS) revoked its cloud hosting services from Parler. Accusing Amazon of violating antitrust laws, Parler writes in its complaint that "AWS's decision to effectively terminate Parler's account is apparently motivated by political animus"

title: (Untitled)
description: Amazon is cutting off Parler's access to its cloud hosting service due to violations of terms of service, particularly the proliferation of violent content on the platform, including posts allegedly inciting the January 6th capitol insurrection. Parler's CEO expressed concerns that the move was a coordinated effort by tech giants to stifle competition, while reaction on the platform ranged from outrage to discussions of violence against Amazon

title: (Untitled)
description: Apple bans Parler from its App Store after the social media platform failed to implement a content moderation plan, following complaints that the app had been used to coordinate the storming of the U.S. Capitol building on January 6th

title: (Untitled)
description: Following Donald Trump's deplatforming from Facebook and Twitter, Parler becomes the number one app in Google's app store. According to data analytics service Sensor Tower, the app saw approximately 210,000 installs globally on 1/8/21, up 281% from approximately 55,000 on 1/7/21

title: (Untitled)
description: Google bans Parler on the Google Play store, citing the company's "longstanding policies" that require apps on the store that display user-generated content to enforce moderation policies

title: (Untitled)
description: Discord bans pro-Trump server 'The Donald' linked to the banned subreddit r/The_Donald the TheDonald.win, following the storming of the U.S. Capital by a pro-Trump mob

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter permanently suspends Trump, citing 'risk of further incitement of violence', following the storming of the U.S. Capitol building on January 6th

title: (Untitled)
description: Reddit bans subreddit group "r/DonaldTrump," citing its policies that "prohibit content that promotes hate, or encourages, glorifies, incites, or calls for violence against groups of people or individuals"

title: (Untitled)
description: WeChat and TikTok see U.S. downloads climb ahead of Trump administration ban

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitch disables President Trump's account following his calls for violence that resulted in the historic riot at the U.S. Capitol

title: (Untitled)
description: YouTube says it will punish Trump and other channels that continue to spread election lies, in the wake of its new policy prohibiting any content designed to spread misinformation about the outcome of the 2020 election. Under the new policy, channels spreading misinformation will receive a strike and be temporarily restricted from posting videos

title: (Untitled)
description: The New York Times reports on how alt-tech platforms such as Gab and Parler were used to organize the January 6th march on the capitol. Following Donald Trump's speech calling on his followers to march on Congress, users and Gab and Parler took to the platforms not only to mobilize fellow Trump supporters, but also to organize their actions, including exchanging tips on how to avoid the police and what tools to bring to pry open doors

title: (Untitled)
description: More than 400 Google engineers and other workers form a minority union that represents a fraction of the company’s more than 260,000 full-time employees and contractors. Workers say it is primarily an effort to give structure and longevity to activism at Google, rather than to negotiate for a contract

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook’s chief of advertising integrity, Rob Leathern, who handled the company’s ad products around sensitive subjects such as politics and coronavirus misinformation, departs, according to an internal company post viewed by Reuters

title: (Untitled)
description: Reuters finds internal documents that suggest Google moved to tighten control over its scientists' papers and, in three instances, requested that authors refrain from casting its technology in a negative light. The new review procedure asks researchers to consult with legal, policy and public relations teams before pursuing topics such as face and sentiment analysis and categorizations of race, gender or political affiliation

title: (Untitled)
description: Telegram announces plan to monetize the platform by introducing an advertising platform for one-to-many channels

title: (Untitled)
description: In an attempt to escape a pair of antitrust lawsuits, Facebook offered the FTC the concession of allowing other firms or developers to license access to its code so that they could more easily create their own version of a social network, among other changes in business practices, the Washington Post reports. Regulators reject the proposal, believing the concessions didn't effectively address competition concerns

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook and Google agreed to “cooperate and assist one another” if they ever faced an investigation into their pact to work together in online advertising, according to an unredacted version of a lawsuit filed by 10 states against Google

title: (Untitled)
description: Substack says readers and writers are really in charge of moderation. The company issues a blogpost outlining a “hands-off approach” to content moderation and plans to "resist public pressure" to remove writers who might be seen as "unacceptable"

title: (Untitled)
description: Gab launches GabTV, a free speech video sharing platform

title: (Untitled)
description: Instagram’s algorithm will either reward or punish you based on your usage of the app as a whole.

title: (Untitled)
description: A conglomerate of U.S. media outlets including the AP, The New York Times, NPR, ESPN, Vox, The Washington Post, Meredith, Bloomberg, NBCU and The Financial Times joins an advocacy group pushing for increased regulation over app stores. The conglomerate, which is represented by the  publisher trade association Digital Content Next, argues that Apple forces publishers to use in-app payments for services like subscriptions, forcing publishers to raise their prices to account for a so-called “Apple tax, ” on the purchases

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitch bans insults like "simp," "incel" and "virgin" under its upcoming revamp of its harassment policy

title: (Untitled)
description: Some product manager announced internally a tool that FB is developing called 'TL;DR'. Basically, it will use AI to summarize long form articles and spit out bullet points so people don't have to read the full piece

title: (Untitled)
description: Google's News Initiative partners with Vox Media on a program called "Language, Please: A Guide for Catalyzing Inclusivity in Newsrooms," which aims to build a number of public resources intended to recognize and impede bias in how journalists report on a broad range of topics. The partnership aims to build a toolkit that will be accessible to local newsrooms

title: (Untitled)
description: Even with a key advantage removed, Google’s AMP likely to stay in publishers’ mobile product plans

title: (Untitled)
description: Reddit has bought TikTok rival Dubsmash to boost video presence

title: (Untitled)
description: Google and Facebook win concessions in a new Australian bill that obliges the two platforms to negotiate supply deals for the right to post media outlets' reports

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook debuts its oversight committee, a panel of twenty lawyers, human rights experts, politicians, and journalists, which will deliberate over an appeals process for those that wish to have posts removed by Facebook reinstated

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook formally announces that "Facebook News," a human-curated product with a select list of publishers including ESI Media, The Guardian, Hearst and Condé Nast, will launch in the U.K. in January. Participating U.K. publishers will receive direct payments from Facebook, sometimes over a period of multiple years, to distribute content they are not currently putting on the platform

title: (Untitled)
description: Google updates its Google News Showcase, now offering users access to paywalled content in partnership with select news publishers as well as a new News Showcase panel, which includes a list of important articles selected daily by publishers. The News Showcase is also expanded to Google News on iOS and news.google.com

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook announces that it will pay mainstream UK news outlets millions of pounds a year to license their articles, which will appear in a dedicated news section on the platform called "Facebook News." The deal comes in the face of a threat from UK regulators to curb the company's dominance of the online advertising market

title: (Untitled)
description: A new U.K. tech regulator plans to limit the power of Google, Facebook and other tech platforms in an attempt to level the playing field for smaller competitors and make a fair market for consumers. Under the plans, the Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) will gain a dedicated Digital Markets Unit, empowered to write and enforce a new code of practice on technology companies which will set out the limits of acceptable behaviour

title: (Untitled)
description: An internal investigation from Facebook found that the company's "Whitelist," a list of about 112,000 accounts belonging to government officials and candidates whose posts couldn’t be fact checked, helped spread misinformation on the platform. Facebook researchers brought evidence to the company that showed individuals on the whitelist were swaying public opinion in an unsuccessful attempt to dissolve the whitelist

title: (Untitled)
description: OANN's YouTube channel is temporarily barred and demonetized by YouTube after the channel uploaded a video promoting a phony cure for COVID-19. The one-week ban issued by YouTube is the first instance of the company cracking down on the OANN's attempts to spread misinformation through the channel

title: (Untitled)
description: Snapchat launches its new feature Spotlight, which functions as a TikTok competitor. The company says it will give away $1 million total to the creators of the top-performing videos on Spotlight each day for the remainder of 2020, and potentially beyond

title: (Untitled)
description: State and federal regulators prepare to bring antitrust charges against Facebook, challenging its acquisitions of WhatsApp and Instagram

title: (Untitled)
description: As Facebook increasingly moderates content containing false claims about the 2020 presidential election, right-wing users, and in particular #Stop the Steal actors, are migrating to other platforms. Parler has seen a surge in sign-ups, with a single-day high of 880,000 installs on November 9th. According to Parler's Chief Operating Officer Jeffrey Wernick, the platform now has 9 million user accounts, compared with 4.5 million about a week ago

title: (Untitled)
description: Despite positioning itself as a platform for free speech, Parler is being critiqued by some left-leaning users, who claim that they were banned from Parler for expressing their viewpoints

title: (Untitled)
description: Google announces that it will include page experience signals in ranking search results, rolling out the feature in May 2021

title: (Untitled)
description: As part of a study, researchers find that a majority of people supported fact-checking with clear differences among Democrats and Republicans. Democratic support shows marginal differences between fact-checks of politicians versus President Trump. A majority of Republicans support fact-checks of politicians but not of Trump

title: (Untitled)
description: In connection with Google's Google News Initiative, the platform has issued grants and funding to media outlets around the globe, notably pro-regime newspapers in countries under autocratic rule. The initiative has funded The New Times, an outlet that functions as a pro-Kagame "mouthpiece" in Rwanda, as well as the United Arab Emirates' English language newspaper, The National, which is owned by a member of the ruling family of Abu Dhabi

title: (Untitled)
description: In a press release, Gab announces that it will not fact check or moderate content relating to the 2020 presidential election. Critiquing "censorship" on platforms such as Twitter and Facebook, Gab writes that "any political speech that is protected by the first amendment of the United States is protected on Gab"

title: (Untitled)
description: In order to understand how consistently and swiftly Facebook applies fact-checks to its namesake platform and Instagram, the Tow Center reviewed fact-checking labels assigned by the company to posts between October 1 and 5—the period spanning President Donald Trump’s COVID-19 diagnosis to his release from Walter Reed Military Hospital following three nights of observation and treatment. The review found that the company failed to consistently label content flagged by its own third-party partners

title: (Untitled)
description: Political advertisements from Joe Biden's election campaign, as well as the Daily Wire and political interest groups, are not labeled by Facebook's transparency system

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook, after telling the public that it would make changes to its news feed to prioritize trusted and informative sources of news, continues to allow right wing "junk sites" to reach users feeds. The platform continues to further restrict the reach of left leaning news sources in January 2018

title: (Untitled)
description: The Justice Department files an antitrust lawsuit against Google alleging that Google uses anticompetitive tactics to preserve a monopoly for its search engine and advertising business

title: (Untitled)
description: Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez Twitch debut, in which she played Among Us and encouraged viewers to vote, becomes one of the platform's biggest broadcasts ever

title: (Untitled)
description: Google launches its "Journalist Studio" with the AI-powered tools "Pinpoint" and "Common Knowledge" as its premiered features. Pinpoint allows journalists to sort through documents, identifying and categorizing frequently referenced people, organizations and locations, while Common Knowledge (developed by Polygraph) is a data visualization tool

title: (Untitled)
description: WordPress introduces a new feature that automatically posts entire blogs as Twitter threads, complete with all text, images, videos and embeds

title: (Untitled)
description: The Washington Post announces it will debut audio election results within select Post podcasts using the publication's "Heliograf" AI technology. The feature will give readers localized results updates for House, Senate and presidential races at the top of "Post Reports," "The Big Idea," and "Can He Do That?" read by an AI voice assistant

title: (Untitled)
description: Google and Facebook have issues classifying publishers as news sources. Facebook allows publishers to self-identify as news sources, allowing anyone to classify themselves as a news source, while Google News' application of its guidelines for identifying news sources has been inconsistent, as identified by the Tow Center

title: (Untitled)
description: Local Media Consortium and Google launch sports collaboration

title: (Untitled)
description: A report by Graphika shows that accounts linked with a Russian disinformation campaign remain active on Gab, despite being banned across other platforms. Parler responded to the report by asserting that because US law enforcement had not contacted them, they did not need to take action. Gab's founder Andrew Torba, on the other hand, asserted that the accounts were free to operate on his platform due to its free speech commitment, as well as insinuated that Graphika had ulterior motives for publishing the report

title: (Untitled)
description: News Corp. CEO Robert Thomson praises Google's new efforts to pay publishers around the world more than $1 billion to license and curate their content

title: (Untitled)
description: Following Facebook's announcement that it would ban all accounts affiliated with the QAnon conspiracy theory, Gab's CEO Andrew Torba writes in a newsletter that "we will be welcoming all QAnon accounts across our social network, news, and encrypted chat platforms"

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitch updates its community guidelines to clarify its ban of terrorist and extremist content

title: (Untitled)
description: Google announces it will give publishers $1 billion for a new product called Google News Showcase

title: (Untitled)
description: After being banned by multiple cloud hosting providers, Gab announces that it has migrated to its own in-house servers

title: (Untitled)
description: Google says it will "broadly block election ads after polls close Nov. 3"

title: (Untitled)
description: The Global Alliance for Responsible Media announces an agreement with Facebook, YouTube, and Twitter, saying they "have agreed to adopt a common framework for defining harmful content that is inappropriate for advertising"

title: (Untitled)
description: The Trump administration announces it will challenge a federal court ruling that temporarily blocked its attempt to curb the use of Chinese messaging and e-commerce app WeChat in the U.S

title: (Untitled)
description: WeChat and TikTok see U.S. downloads climb ahead of Trump administration ban

title: (Untitled)
description: Mark Zuckerberg announced Facebook's collaboration with the United Nations Foundation and WHO to create a COVID-19 Solidarity Response Fund, matching donations up to $20 million to support global and U.S. efforts against the outbreak

title: (Untitled)
description: Google announces the GNI Digital Growth Program to help "small and mid-sized news publishers around the world develop the capabilities required to accelerate the growth of their businesses online"

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter launches 2020 election hub, which will include local news, curated news, and debate live streams, among other features

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook announces $5 million spend on local news with a focus on diversity and entrepreneurship

title: (Untitled)
description: YouTube starts rolling out its TikTok competitor, YouTube Shorts

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook, Google, Twitter, and Reddit meet with each other and with law enforcement officials to "discuss potential threats to election integrity"

title: (Untitled)
description: Mark Zuckerberg announces in a Facebook post that the company is taking a number of steps ahead of the election, in anticipation of both "misinformation" and "civil unrest," including a partnership with Reuters and the National Election Pool to provide authoritative information about election results

title: (Untitled)
description: Google launches Your News Update, a "smart playlist" in Google Podcasts that will provide local news, among other content, to users

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook publishes recommendation guidelines that will determine what content can be recommended to its users

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook announces that it "will reluctantly stop allowing publishers and people in Australia from sharing local and international news on Facebook and Instagram," should Australia's government pass legislation that requires Facebook to pay news publishers for content on its platform

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook announces an "account linking tool" that it is testing with select publishers that would allow users to "see and access content from publishers they subscribe to"

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook announces it will expand its News product to the UK, Germany, France, India and Brazil

title: (Untitled)
description: WordPress founding developer Matt Mullenweg accuses Apple of cutting off the ability to update the WordPress app — until or unless he adds in-app purchases so Apple can extract its 30 percent cut of the money

title: (Untitled)
description: Major news publishers ask Apple what can get them an App Store deal like Amazon’s

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter bans BitChute from tweeting, blocking all tweets and retweets containing links to BitChute videos. In response, BitChute claims Twitter's actions are unjust and urges users to share their experiences of being blocked

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook will no longer allow "news" organizations backed by politically-motivated individuals or entities to obtain a "news exemption" from its political ads requirements

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter begins to label "government and state-affiliated media accounts"

title: (Untitled)
description: Instagram launches Reels, its attempt to keep you off TikTok

title: (Untitled)
description: Biden's campaign team is told they cannot have TikTok on their devices

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitch viewership increases significantly since the start of the pandemic, growing to 5 billion hours watched between April and June

title: (Untitled)
description: Research by Hope Not Hate demonstrates that BitChute serves as a hub for terrorist propaganda, incitement to racist violence, and COVID-19 misinformation. According to Hope Note Hate's investigation, BitChute hosts 114 video supporting proscribed terrorist groups, including National Action and the Islamic State, while also promoting conspiracy theories and misinformation. The organization urges major social media platforms to ban BitChute links, and calls for law enforcement to investigate its content for violations of British law, including terrorism legislation

title: (Untitled)
description: Apple launches Apple News Today, a news podcast

title: (Untitled)
description: Apple News adds new audio features, including a daily briefing, alongside expanded local coverage

title: (Untitled)
description: A conference paper presented at the 31st ACM Conference on Hypertext and Social Media provides a preliminary analysis of content and discourse on BitChute. The authors find that only a handful of BitChute channels receive user engagement and that the platform "has a higher rate of hate speech than Gab but less than 4chan." They conclude that BitChute's high rate of hate speech, and in particular anti-Semitism, is concerning and raises questions about the environment created by "low content moderation" platforms

title: (Untitled)
description: Tow Center: "For Facebook, a boycott and a long, draw-out reckoning"

title: (Untitled)
description: Google News Initiative and LION Publishers launch GNI Startups Lab, for news entrepreneurs

title: (Untitled)
description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo states that the U.S. is looking into banning TikTok

title: (Untitled)
description: Pinterest explores revenue-share model with publishers in video-driven advertising experiment

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook begins to allow for journalists to register, as long as their news organization has a registered page

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook says it will prioritize original reporting and ‘transparent authorship’ in the News Feed

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook will change its algorithm to prioritize original reporting

title: (Untitled)
description: Apple News loses The New York Times

title: (Untitled)
description: Tow Center: "Tech platforms have a trust problem. Do they care?"

title: (Untitled)
description: Google announces it will begin "surfacing fact check information in Google Images"

title: (Untitled)
description: Gab announces that it has been blacklisted by Visa for "promoting hate speech." Andrew Torba disputes Visa's claim, writing that "Gab is a neutral technology platform," and asks that all subscription payments and donations be sent via echeck, check by mail, or bitcoin to Gab

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook announces it will "block ads from state-controlled media outlets targeted to people in the US"

title: (Untitled)
description: In an op-ed for USA Today, Mark Zuckerberg announces that Facebook users will be able to turn off political ads

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter announces it will begin testing a feature to ask users whether they want to read an article before they retweet it, if the user has not opened that article

title: (Untitled)
description: Google, the Local Media Association and Local Media Consortium—which together represent more than 5,000 news outlets in the U.S. and Canada—are launch the 'Support Local News' campaign across a breadth of local outlets that includes media organizations of color. ($15 million campaign)

title: (Untitled)
description: Tow Center: "As publishers rethink editorial norms, social media policies must follow"

title: (Untitled)
description: After Microsoft lays off the editorial staff of MSN, an "experimental feature" in its automated system incorrectly illustrated a news story about racism with a photo of the wrong mixed-race member of the band Little Mix

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook announces it will label "state-controlled media"

title: (Untitled)
description: The Facebook Journalism Project announces it is partnering with the International News Media Association (INMA) on a program that will give U.S. local news publishers access to INMA’s Readers First Initiative. The partnership will connect 20 U.S. media companies with INMA’s global membership and innovation network for up to two years of unlimited access to full benefits of INMA corporate members. The Facebook Journalism Project will provide a full year of INMA corporate membership free followed by a second discounted year

title: (Untitled)
description: More than 25 employees of PA Media who maintain news pages on MSN's website and the Edge browser lose their jobs after Microsoft decides to instead use AI to select, edit and curate news articles on its homepages

title: (Untitled)
description: Amazon is looking to invest in local podcasts

title: (Untitled)
description: The Facebook Journalism Project (FJP) is announces $390,000 to help South African news organizations navigate the economic impact of the COVID-19

title: (Untitled)
description: Despite Facebook and YouTube largely removing the debunked COVID-19 documentary "Plandemic," variations continue to proliferate on alternative social media sites like BitChute and Gab, drawing hundreds of thousands of views. Links to these versions resurface on mainstream platforms, undermining efforts to curb misinformation. These alt-tech platforms, which emphasize uncensored free speech, serve as reservoirs for flagged content, allowing it to persist and spread

title: (Untitled)
description: Grow with Google and the National Congress of American Indians announce a partnership to help create economic opportunity in Native communities. The signature piece of this partnership is the NCAI Indian Country Digital Trainers Program, which offers Grow with Google training for small businesses and job seekers in Native communities

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter announces they have added a new tab in Explore so it’s easier to find the latest information on COVID-19

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook will buy Giphy for $400 million and integrate it into Instagram

title: (Untitled)
description: The Facebook Journalism Project (FJP) announces $750,000 in funding and training to help news organizations in the Middle East and North Africa navigate the impact of COVID-19

title: (Untitled)
description: Apple is in talks with publishers to create audio versions of their stories for Apple News+

title: (Untitled)
description: Google announces support links for businesses to post directly to their Business Profiles on Google, starting first in the U.S., Canada, U.K., Ireland, Australia and New Zealand. With this feature, merchants will be able to add a donation link, gift card link or both to their profile. They can also share a personal message in their post to inform customers how funds will be put to use

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter announces they will be introducing new labels and warning messages that will provide additional context and information on some Tweets containing disputed or misleading information related to COVID-19. These labels will link to a Twitter-curated page or external trusted source containing additional information on the claims made within the Tweet. Depending on the propensity for harm and type of misleading information, warnings may also be applied to a Tweet. These warnings will inform people that the information in the Tweet conflicts with public health experts’ guidance before they view it

title: (Untitled)
description: Google announces when users search for information about mental health conditions they will provide panels with information from authoritative sources like Mayo Clinic that detail symptoms, treatments, and provide an overview of the different types of specialists who can help. On the info panels for depression and post traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). Google will provide direct access to clinically-validated self-assessment questionnaires that ask some of the same types of questions a mental health professional might ask. Based on a person’s answers, these self-assessment tools provide information on risk, along with links to more resources. Results to these questionnaires will not be logged

title: (Untitled)
description: Google announce 'Be Kind to Your Mind, ' which includes resources on mental wellbeing from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Whenever people in the U.S. search for information about coping with the pandemic, or on COVID-19 and mental health, we'll show a public service announcement with tips to cope with stress during COVID-19

title: (Untitled)
description: Apple announces it will award $10 million from its Advanced Manufacturing Fund to COPAN Diagnostics, a market leader in sample collection kits that play a critical role in COVID-19 testing

title: (Untitled)
description: Google announces that Google.org Fellows will give a total of 50,000 hours to COVID-19-specific projects

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook announces a soft launch of Discover, "a new product that builds on our Free Basics initiative," and provides users in select countries with free data

title: (Untitled)
description: YouTube plans to allow publishers to use their YouTube channels to sell subscriptions to their owned properties

title: (Untitled)
description: Apple News hits 125 million monthly active users

title: (Untitled)
description: The Facebook Journalism Project is announces a $2 million investment in grant funding, coaching and training to support Asia-Pacific news organizations’ coronavirus work

title: (Untitled)
description: YouTube announces they are expanding their fact check information panels to the U.S.

title: (Untitled)
description: The Facebook Journalism Project announces a partnership with the International Center for Journalists (ICFJ), a nonprofit organization focused on promoting quality journalism around the world, "to launch a $2 million fund that will help news organizations in Latin America during the COVID-19 crisis." (Later named: The Facebook Journalism Project / ICFJ COVID-19 Latin America News Relief Fund Grant Program)

title: (Untitled)
description: YouTube announces it will provide $1M through the Google News Initiative to the IFCN to "bolster fact-checking and verification efforts across the world"

title: (Untitled)
description: WhatsApp says its forwarding limits have cut the spread of viral messages by 70 percent

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook launches "Messenger Rooms"

title: (Untitled)
description: Google announces it will require all advertisers on its platform to verify their identity

title: (Untitled)
description: Google announces more than $200,000 in grants as part of a new Vulnerability Research Grant COVID-19 fund for Google VRP researchers who help identify various vulnerabilities

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook announces a $260,000 grant to support NetHope’s COVID-19 response and will begin sharing their Disease Prevention Maps to help NetHope identify vulnerable and affected communities, including migrants and refugees, in order to provide them with protective health equipment and internet connectivity kits

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter announces unverified claims related to COVID 19 that have the potential to incite people to action, could lead to the destruction or damage of critical infrastructure, or cause widespread panic/social unrest may be considered a violation of their policies

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook announces a $2 million grant to support ITDRC’s projectConnect initiative which will help rural and underserved communities in the U.S. gain access to the internet and will share insights from Facebook Disease Prevention Maps to help ITDRC better understand options for internet coverage in specific regions to determine the type of support needed to address connectivity challenges

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook announces it will "provide the location of high-reach Facebook Pages and Instagram accounts on every post they share, so people have more information to help them gauge the reliability and authenticity of the content they see in their feeds"

title: (Untitled)
description: The Compass Experiment, a partnership between Google News Initiative’s Local Experiments Project and McClatchy, will launch a local newsroom in Colorado called The Longmont Leader

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook announces it will begin working with partners to bring a small number of content reviewers, on a voluntary basis, back to offices to support increased need

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook, Amazon, Hewlett Packard, IBM, and Microsoft sign the Open COVID Patent Pledge to help make patents freely available in the fight against COVID-19

title: (Untitled)
description: Clubhouse voice chat leads a wave of spontaneous social apps

title: (Untitled)
description: Google announces they will waive ad serving fees for news publishers globally on Ad Manager for five months

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook announces a new section on their COVID-19 Information Center called Get the Facts. It includes fact-checked articles from partners that debunk misinformation about the coronavirus. The fact-checked articles are selected by Facebook's News curation team and updated every week

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook announces that more than 1,000 media professionals across the region have joined our Digital Media Bootcamp: COVID-19 Edition to learn product best practices for coverage of COVID-19. Sessions have cover topics such as how to use Facebook and Instagram Live, tips for working from home and mental health and wellness advice

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook announces it will start showing messages in News Feed to people who have liked, reacted or commented on harmful misinformation about COVID-19 that we have since removed. "These messages will connect people to COVID-19 myths debunked by the WHO including ones we've removed from our platform for leading to imminent physical harm"

title: (Untitled)
description: Google announces Google.org is giving $1 million collectively to the International Center for Journalists and the Columbia Journalism School's Dart Center for Journalism and Trauma

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook announces Instagram will make it easier to discover gift cards, online food orders, and fundraisers on Instagram to help support the businesses

title: (Untitled)
description: Google announces nonprofits can activate G Suite for Nonprofits at no cost and collaborate online with apps like Gmail, Docs, and Calendar. In addition, advanced features of Google Meet are available to all editions of G Suite through September 30, 2020. In addition their  Ad Grants Crisis Response Program is extending Ad Grants, up to $10,000 worth of text-based Search ads at no cost through October 2020. The YouTube Nonprofit Program and Google Earth and Maps will also offer nonprofits storytelling tools to amplify their cause. To give more nonprofits access to G Suite’s advanced features, Google is launching nonprofit discounts globally for G Suite Business ($4 per user per month, normally offered at $12) and G Suite Enterprise ($8 per user per month, normally offered at $25)

title: (Untitled)
description: The Google News Initiative launches the Journalism Emergency Relief Fund to deliver aid to thousands of small, medium and local news publishers globally. The funding is open to news organizations producing original news for local communities and will range from the low thousands of dollars for small hyper-local newsrooms to low tens of thousands for larger newsrooms, with variations per region. A follow up announcement on May 28 added that more than 5,300 small and medium local newsrooms around the world will receive funding ranging from $5,000 - $30,000. Applications covering a number of publications under one organization will be capped at $85,000. As we await a final funding tally, we expect to spend tens of millions of dollars through the Journalism Emergency Relief Fund

title: (Untitled)
description: Apple announces they have sourced and donated well over 20 million face masks for medical professionals on the front lines around the world

title: (Untitled)
description: Apple announces Siri Audio Briefs for COVID-19 to help customers receive the latest news and information about the pandemic through short podcasts from trusted news providers and Siri can also provide guidance and resources from the CDC if asked, "How do I know if I have coronavirus?"

title: (Untitled)
description: Apple Maps prioritizes grocery, food delivery, and medical services when searching nearby

title: (Untitled)
description: Apple announces they helped Stanford Medicine build a new app for first responders to help screen their symptoms and, if needed, schedule testing

title: (Untitled)
description: Apple announces a curated collection of telehealth apps are available in the App Store

title: (Untitled)
description: Apple announces their company and its suppliers to design and produce face shields, and is shipping 1 million face masks per week to the areas that need them most

title: (Untitled)
description: Apple releases a mobility data trends tool from Apple Maps to support work happening around the globe to mitigate the spread of COVID-19. This mobility data may provide helpful insights to local governments and health authorities and may also be used as a foundation for new public policies by showing the change in volume of people driving, walking or taking public transit in their communities

title: (Untitled)
description: Google and Apple announce a joint effort to enable the use of Bluetooth technology to help governments and health agencies reduce the spread of the virus, with user privacy and security central to the design. The two companies will be launching a comprehensive solution that includes application programming interfaces (APIs) and operating system-level technology to assist in enabling contact tracing. In May, both companies will release APIs that enable interoperability between Android and iOS devices using apps from public health authorities and in the coming months, Apple and Google will work to enable a broader Bluetooth-based contact tracing platform by building this functionality into their underlying platforms. They emphasise that this is a more robust solution than an API and would allow more individuals to participate, if they choose to opt in, as well as enable interaction with a broader ecosystem of apps and government health authorities

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter announces it is joining in partnership with the Center for Safe Internet Pharmacies, building on its collaboration with Google, Facebook, and Microsoft to showcase a variety of resources on TechTogether.co to support the #RecoveryMovement. The site is a collection of resources to help those experiencing a substance use disorder and the associated stigma

title: (Untitled)
description: Google announces healthcare providers like hospitals, doctors, and mental health professionals can now enter a virtual care offering in their Business Profile, so that users searching for their local providers see a 'get online care' link on Search and Maps and  automatically surfacing a link directly to health providers’ COVID-19 information page on Search and Maps

title: (Untitled)
description: Google begins a pilot in the U.S. showing widely-available virtual care platforms directly on Search so people can more easily access virtual visits

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook announces they are donating $2 million to support organizations like Vibrant Emotional Health that operates the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline in the U.S., Kids Help Phone in Canada, iCALL Psychosocial Helpline in India, Samaritans in the U.K., Centro de Valorização da Vida in Brazil and more

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook announces an Instagram Live series from Netflix called 'Wanna Talk About It?'. They also announce they are working on an Instagram Live series with  the National Alliance on Mental Illness to encourage conversations about mental health and promote activities to help people stay well

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook adds Quiet Mode which can mute most push notifications

title: (Untitled)
description: The Facebook Journalism Project (FJP) and the European Journalism Centre (EJC) announce the European Journalism COVID-19 Support Fund. EJC will direct emergency funds via the $3 million that Facebook is investing into small and mid-sized news organizations and journalists

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook announces it will limit forwards on WhatsApp to one chat at a time

title: (Untitled)
description: The Facebook Journalism Project (FJP) launches the FJP COVID-19 Local News Relief Fund Grant Program, offering grant opportunities to help U.S. local news organizations continue serving communities during the COVID 19 outbreak (This development is related to the March 30 announcement of $25 million in grants. Each grant can be between $25,000 and $100,000)

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook changes Groups to show members of COVID-19 related groups an educational pop-up directing them to credible information from health organizations and prompt group admins to share Live broadcasts about COVID-19 from health authorities

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter partners with the WHO to provide answers to commonly asked questions about COVID-19

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook announces new Data for Good tools to support health researchers and nonprofits: Three new types of Disease Prevention Maps to help inform disease forecasting efforts and protective measures, using aggregated data to protect people’s privacy; A prompt on Facebook encouraging people in the U.S. to participate in a voluntary survey from Carnegie Mellon University Delphi Research Center designed to help health researchers identify COVID-19 hotspots earlier

title: (Untitled)
description: Google launches a "COVID-19 experience on Google News," which includes local coverage, fact checks, and links to health information

title: (Untitled)
description: Google announces they are collaborating with select epidemiologists working on COVID 19 with updates to an existing aggregate, anonymized dataset that can be used to better understand and forecast the pandemic

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook hosts an exclusive Facebook event called COVID FRONTLINE with reporters from 7News Australia, South China Morning Post, and The Straits Times on Facebook watch

title: (Untitled)
description: As part of its COVID-19 response, Telegram launches a verification process to distinguish trustworthy sources of health information. In a blog post, the company writes: "to make sure users find accurate and relevant information about the pandemic in their region, we've created a special channel which shows up as the top result for all coronavirus-related keywords in Search. It contains a list of official news sources by country"

title: (Untitled)
description: Google announces the early release of their COVID-19 Community Mobility Reports to provide insights into what has changed in response to work from home, shelter in place, and other policies aimed at flattening the curve of the pandemic. They will release these reports globally, initially covering 131 countries and regions

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook allows business owners to create personal fundraisers on Facebook

title: (Untitled)

Participants will receive unique access to Messenger tools and content as well as educational materials from Facebook to support their innovation. The winners will get mentoring from Facebook engineers to help make their idea a reality

title: (Untitled)

description: Facebook announces when users report content that they believe violates policies, they will see a new message letting them know that they have fewer content reviewers available and will prioritize reported content that has the greatest potential ​to harm the community. This means some reports will not be reviewed as quickly as they used to be and they will not get to some reports at all. Appeals will likely not be reviewed

title: (Untitled)

title: (Untitled)

Disbursement was announced on April 7: 400 newsrooms were given $5,000 each. This was later named the COVID-19 Community Network grant program; see March 30 announcement, which builds upon this)

description: BitChute is one of a set of gaming and video sharing platforms that are exempt from Germany's NetzDG, a new proposed law to toughen online speech regulations that will require social media platforms like Facebook and Twitter to report certain hate speech and criminal posts to the police. This law obliges platforms to delete illegal content within 24 hours and flag it to the Office of the Federal Criminal Police. Critics argue that far-right influencers use platforms like BitChute to evade stricter regulations on mainstream sites, thus reducing the effectiveness of the law

description: According to a report from the Anti Defamation League, Telegram has become a popular platform for international white supremacist and extremist groups, hosting more than 221,000 channels and groups, some of which disseminate violent and racist content. Despite Telegram's terms of service prohibiting violence promotion, it's easy to find such content, including videos from white supremacist mass shooters, indicating a lack of active enforcement

description: Facebook announces new measures to "protect the 2020 U.S. Elections," including, for example, "labelling state-controlled media, and launching a new product called Facebook Protect for elected officials, candidates, their staff and others who may be particularly vulnerable to targeting by hackers and foreign adversaries." description: Approximately 200,000 Twitter users, believed to be from Saudi Arabia, have migrated to Parler and overwhelmed the platform, crashing some of the site's functions. These new users have doubled Parler's user base as they seek an alternative to perceived censorship on Twitter. Parler, initially a platform for U.S. Trump supporters, now finds itself hosting an unexpected mix of Saudi nationalists and American conservatives, prompting varied reactions among users

description: According to an investigation by Vice, Facebook has made changes to its powerful Graph Search function to limit the data it provides to users. This function has been abused by bad actors and used by good ones to access critical information quickly

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter updates its platform rules to make them more "simple," including creating new categories for them (safety, privacy and authenticity) and expanding detail in specific areas, such as "election integrity, platform manipulation and spam"

title: (Untitled)
description: Search Engine Land publishes data on the "winners" and "losers" from Google's changes to its search algorithm. The Daily Mail, for example, says it lost 50% of its referral traffic from search

title: (Untitled)
description: YouTube publishes a blog post on their "ongoing work to tackle hate" on their platform, including boosting more "authoritative" content, and prohibiting videos alleging that a group is superior in order to justify discrimination, segregation or exclusion based on qualities like age, gender, race, caste, religion, sexual orientation or veteran status. This would include, for example, videos that promote or glorify Nazi ideology, which is inherently discriminatory. Finally, we will remove content denying that well-documented violent events, like the Holocaust or the shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary, took place

title: (Untitled)
description: Privacy concerns caused WhatsApp founders Brian Acton and Jan Koum to leave Facebook

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook makes several announcements related to reader revenue supported publishers. This includes the rollout of News Funding, a product for membership supported publications, and the expansion of subscriptions through Instant Articles to all publishers

title: (Untitled)
description: Telegram is enhancing its privacy features by introducing granular settings for group chats, allowing users to control visibility for different groups independently. Additionally, a new privacy control enables users to selectively reveal their phone numbers

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter will study whether deplatforming is the best way to deal with white supremacists

title: (Untitled)
description: Google announces a local news "innovation challenge" through which selected projects will receive up to $300,000 from the Google News Initiative

title: (Untitled)
description: Neo-Nazis and white supremacists share Hitler-related propaganda in an effort to recruit new members on TikTok, according to a new report from the Institute for Strategic Dialogue

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook removes 265 Facebook and Instagram accounts, pages, groups, and events linked to Israel with "coordinated inauthentic behavior" focused on African countries, Latin America, and Southeast Asia

title: (Untitled)
description: Google announces that ads will appear in more places across its products, including Maps and in image galleries

title: (Untitled)
