description: In response to the Christchurch attack in New Zealand, Facebook announces that certain users, such as those who have broken rules or the company's "Dangerous Organizations and Individuals" policy, will lose access to Live for a period of time

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter, in an effort to curb misinformation about vaccines, announces that, going forward, "when someone searches for certain keywords associated with vaccines, a prompt will direct individuals to a credible public health resource"

title: (Untitled)
description: Tow Center: "Audit suggests Google favors a small number of major outlets"

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook announces updates to its video ranking algorithm. With the update, video rankings and distribution will increasingly be determined by "1) loyalty and intent, 2) video and viewing durations and 3) originality"

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter updates the retweet function to allow for GIFs and other media to accompany a retweet, in addition to text

title: (Untitled)
description: Amazon is offering publishers like the New York Times and BuzzFeed money upfront if they expand globally, and, by extension, expand the reach of Amazon's affiliate links

title: (Untitled)
description: Instagram is suppressing "debunked" posts as part of Facebook's broader fact checking efforts

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook removes 97 accounts, pages, and groups linked to Russia and involved in "coordinated inauthentic behavior"

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook announces that it is recruiting financial entities to help launch crypto payments on its platform. The effort is part of the company's broader privacy plan

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook (and Instagram) bans Alex Jones, Milo Yiannopoulos, and other individuals and entities responsible for spreading misinformation and far-right extremism and who "promote or engage in violence and hate"

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook redesigns its mobile app and website to emphasize privacy. Mark Zuckerberg told the NYT that the changes “will end up creating a more trustworthy platform”

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter announces live video partnerships with media companies including the Wall Street Journal, Time, and Univision

title: (Untitled)
description: Tow Center: "What is machine learning and why should I care?"

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter unveils a feature to make it easier for users to report content that attempts to mislead voters and undermine elections

title: (Untitled)
description: Amidst several high profile departures from the company, Facebook announces that Jennifer Newstead will become general counsel and John Pinette will be VP of global communication

title: (Untitled)
description: NBC News reports that Facebook leveraged, and seriously considered selling, user data to companies, according to leaked documents

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook announces next steps in its effort toward "integrity" on the platform, including a "Click-Gap" signal that would indicate whether a piece of content is overperforming on the platform relative to its authority and relevance across the internet

title: (Untitled)
description: Snapchat announces the Snap Audience Network, which will allow ads run through the network to also appear on third-party apps, similar to Facebook's ad platform

title: (Untitled)
description: Mark Zuckerberg says that he is considering creating a separate section on the site for "high-quality news" and paying those publishers a fee

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook announces that the company has removed 200 accounts across Facebook and Instagram involved with "coordinated inauthentic behavior" in the Philippines

title: (Untitled)
description: Following criticism, Google has removed a "conversion therapy" app from its store

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook releases a new Ad Library to increase transparency around ads across its platforms

title: (Untitled)
description: After submitting a filing to sell stocks to SEC on March 28th, Gab abruptly withdraws its request, signaling that it will pursue alternative sources of financing

title: (Untitled)
description: Tow Center: "Do technology companies care about journalism?"

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook announces a "ban on praise, support and representation of white nationalism and white separatism on Facebook and Instagram"

title: (Untitled)
description: Google will directly fund the creation of local newsrooms with its new Local Experiments Project

title: (Untitled)
description: Apple formally unveils Apple News Plus, its previously announced bundle of news and magazine publishers

title: (Untitled)
description: Google releases an analytics tool for publishers called Real-time Content Insights

title: (Untitled)
description: In a blog post entitled "Taking Back Our Privacy," Telegram announces platform updates aimed at increasing user control over their data. This includes the ability to unsend any message and forward content anonymously

title: (Untitled)
description: Google announces the launch of the GNI Subscriptions Lab to help publishers “transform their approach to digital subscriptions," among other updates to its Google News Initiative

title: (Untitled)
description: Apple announces that it will support the News Literacy Project and other media literacy programs

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook publishes a post about their research into news deserts, which found that "about one in three users in the U.S. live in places where we cannot find enough local news on Facebook to launch Today In"

title: (Untitled)
description: Telegram reports 3 million news signups following a temporary outage of Facebook apps

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook executives Chris Cox, who had been with the company for more than a decade, and Chris Daniels abruptly leave the company

title: (Untitled)
description: Telegram reports 3 million news signups following a temporary outage of Facebook apps

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook is under criminal investigation by federal prosecutors for its data deals, including with two top smartphone makers

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter begins to roll out its new prototype app, which includes hidden engagement and color coded replies in threads to indicate the original poster, among other changes intended to improve conversation on the platform

title: (Untitled)
description: CNN is expanding its partnership with Twitter to enhance advertising opportunities on the platform, capitalizing on the surging user growth of the news brand. Advertisers now have the chance to purchase ads specifically around popular Twitter videos from CNN, such as impactful moments from debates or exclusive interviews, providing targeted exposure previously unavailable

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook publishes a blog post on "combatting vaccine misinformation," and said they would reject ads and reduce group and page rankings for entities spreading vaccine misinformation content

title: (Untitled)
description: YouTube will start displaying "information panels" next to search results about topics "prone to misinformation" in India. YouTube plans to roll these changes out globally but declines to provide a timeline

title: (Untitled)
description: Mark Zuckerberg publishes a blog post called "A Privacy-Focused Vision for Social Networking," in which he describes a move toward encryption and "reducing permanence"

title: (Untitled)
description: Google will ban political advertising in Canada ahead of the federal election in response to new legislation in Canada requiring platforms to maintain a database of all politicals ads run on their platform

title: (Untitled)
description: YouTube announces that it will not run advertisements on videos related to the Momo challenge, a viral hoax

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter confirms that the company is working on a feature to allow users to hide tweets in response to conversations they begin

title: (Untitled)
description: Gab's new browser extension, Dissenter, allows users to comment on any webpage, expanding the platform's reach beyond its own site. With features like up- and down-voting and visibility to anyone, Dissenter advertises itself as creating a "public square" for online discussions. It requires a Gab account for commenting

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook will not renew two-thirds of its news shows on Watch

title: (Untitled)
description: YouTube disallows channels that promote anti-vaccination content from running advertisements

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter co-founder Evan Williams announces that he will leave the company's board

title: (Untitled)
description: Disney and Nestle pause ad spending on YouTube after their ads were shown next to explicit videos

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook announces a new program to fund publisher shows featuring influencers on Watch

title: (Untitled)
description: Snapchat announces that it will pay $50,000 per original episode of Snapchat Discover shows

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook is negotiating with the FTC regarding what could potentially be a record multi-billion dollar fine over Facebook's data privacy

title: (Untitled)
description: Publishers are displeased with Apple's revenue share proposal for its new bundled subscription news product, which involves Apple taking 50% and publishers splitting the rest

title: (Untitled)
description: LinkedIn launches live video product called LinkedIn Live

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook announces multiple plans oriented around community-building, including allowing a fundraising sticker on Instagram and expanding subscription groups

title: (Untitled)
description: YouTube's former Global Head of Creative Insights, Vanessa Pappas, becomes TikTok's U.S. General Manager

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook head of communications Caryn Marooney is leaving the company

title: (Untitled)
description: Spotify gets serious about podcasts by acquiring Gimlet Media and Anchor

title: (Untitled)
description: At an event, Facebook's head of global news partnerships Campbell Brown reiterated that the platform could not save publishers. "Facebook cannot be the entire solution to your problems," Brown said. "By its very nature, Facebook is constantly changing and not dependable"

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook removes another 22 pages linked to Alex Jones and InfoWars as part of its recidivism policy

title: (Untitled)
description: Reddit is leading another round and seeks between $150 - $300 million in Series D funding. The Chinese tech giant Tencent leads the funding round

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook has acquired the team behind blockchain company Chainspace

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitch is now the most popular streaming platform for gamers, with 15 million daily users watching 2.2 million broadcasters

title: (Untitled)
description: Snopes withdraws from Facebook's fact checking partnership

title: (Untitled)
description: Tow Center: "Boosting local news with data journalism and automation"

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook removes hundreds of accounts from Iran engaged in "coordinated inauthentic behavior" and Twitter notes takedowns of accounts from Iran, as well as Bangladesh, Russia, and Venezuela

title: (Untitled)
description: Apple announces that Facebook Research VPN, an app that paid users for their data, violates its policies and bans the app. This follows the publication of an investigation of Facebook Research VPN by Reuters

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook releases the draft charter for its forthcoming Oversight Board, which will be an independent body that reviews Facebook's content decisions

title: (Untitled)
description: Snapchat announces that it is considering permanent Snaps

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook plans to integrate WhatsApp, Instagram, and Messenger

title: (Untitled)
description: YouTube announces they will reduce "recommendations of borderline content and content that could misinform users in harmful ways," which, they say, will apply to <1% of content

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook will shut down its Moments photo app on February 25th

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter is testing an "Original Tweeter" tag to identify the origin of a thread

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook will begin removing Pages and Groups if they are part of a network or coordinated effort that violates Community Standards

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook launches Community Actions, a petition-like feature on its News Feed

title: (Untitled)
description: In an effort to curb the spread of misinformation, WhatsApp will limit the number of times a user can forward a message. Users can now forward a message a maximum of five times, in comparison to the previous limit of twenty

title: (Untitled)
description: Tow Center: "Facebook should treat the cause, not the symptoms, of journalism’s plight"

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook advertising rules will become stricter in countries where elections will take place in 2019

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook announces the company will put $300 million toward supporting local news initiatives over three years

title: (Untitled)
description: WordPress.com VIP invests in The News Project, a full-service publishing platform specifically built for digital news publishers

title: (Untitled)
description: BitChute announces that it is moving its domain names over to Epik, a domain registrar and cloud-hosting company known for providing services to alt-tech platforms. In a post on Gab, BitChute writes, "Just to reassure everyone that our domain is not currently under attack or facing any issues with our current provider. This is purely because we would like to move to Epik after chatting to the owner Rob Monster we are confident we'll be in good hands"

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook is investigating potentially misleading political ads from News for Democracy, which is backed by billionaire Reid Hoffman

title: (Untitled)
description: Cryptocurrency exchange platform Coinbase closes the accounts of Gab and its founder, Andrew Torba

title: (Untitled)
description: Pinterest removes three prominent "natural health" pages for peddling health misinformation

title: (Untitled)
description: The New York Times reports that Facebook quietly gave companies like Microsoft, Amazon, and Spotify more user data than previously known

title: (Untitled)
description: Tow Center: "Jonathan Albright on the new Senate report, and the importance of Instagram to Russian disinformation"

title: (Untitled)
description: Google News Initiative announces YouTube "innovation funding" for 87 newsrooms across the globe to expand video capabilities

title: (Untitled)
description: Tow Center: "Apple News UK editors rely on six outlets for 75 percent of Top Stories"

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook responds to a Guardian story about a loss of faith among the platform's fact-checking partners. In a blog post entitled "A Fact Check on Fact-Checking," Facebook claims that the Guardian's piece contains inaccuracies and is based on a single source with limited experience

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook tells news executives that it will cut its spending on some news shows on Watch (total budget estimated to be ~$90 million). The same day, Facebook announces that Watch has "75 million daily visitors spend more than 20 minutes in Watch"

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook apologizes for exposing private photos of millions of users due to a bug that had gone unnoticed

title: (Untitled)
description: Tow Center: "Google’s Dragonfly will intensify surveillance on journalists in China"

title: (Untitled)
description: Tow Center: "Digital influencers have changed advertising. they're changing journalism, too"

title: (Untitled)
description: Google's smart phones and speakers will have an audio version of Google News, driven by voice and AI

title: (Untitled)
description: UK Parliament releases internal Facebook documents that news outlets in November reported had been obtained. The documents show how the company handled user data, from granting certain entities special access to discussing ways to monetize that data. Mark Zuckerberg took to Facebook to dispute the media coverage of those docs, writing "We've never sold anyone's data. ... it's also important that the coverage of what we do -- including the explanation of these internal documents -- doesn't misrepresent our actions or motives"

title: (Untitled)
description: Tow Center report: "Guide to Advertising Technology"

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook will no longer include news publishers' promoted content as part of its political ads archive, a move that for months upset news publishers

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook Journalism Project will partner with International Center for Journalists to train more than 2,000 journalists in the Middle East and North Africa to identify online misinformation

title: (Untitled)
description: The House Judiciary Committee announces a December hearing with Google CEO Sundar Pichai regarding the company's data collection and use, and content filtering

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook launches Today In, a section for local news and information

title: (Untitled)
description: Tow Center: "An algorithmic nose for news"

title: (Untitled)
description: Parliament has obtained internal Facebook documents that contain information related to the Cambridge Analytica scandal. The documents were handed over by a U.S. software company, Six4Three, that took legal action against Facebook for exploiting loopholes in its privacy policy

title: (Untitled)
description: Mark Zuckerberg will send Facebook's VP of policy solutions Richard Allan to testify in his place before lawmakers from seven countries. The lawmakers responded with a statement, “The Committee still believes that Mark Zuckerberg is the appropriate person to answer important questions about data privacy, safety, security and sharing"

title: (Untitled)
description: Google launches a local social app only in India called Neighbourly

title: (Untitled)
description: Tow Center report: "Facebook and The Innovator’s Dilemma"

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook awards £4.5 million to support 80 local newsroom jobs in Britain

title: (Untitled)
description: Google considers shutting down Google News in the EU in response to a plan that would require Google to pay for aggregating publisher links

title: (Untitled)
description: An investigation published by the New York Times found that, among many other things, the company executives (including Sheryl Sandberg) tried to obfuscate an investigation by its own security team (led by Alex Stamos) into alarming Russian activity on the platform. Facebook disputed the findings

title: (Untitled)
description: BitChute's CEO, Ray Vahey, announces that PayPal has refused payment processing services to the platform. This comes shortly after PayPal cancelled the accounts of several far-right and anti-fascist groups, citing concerns over their promotion of hate, violence, and discrimination

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook has hired Anne Kornblut to the newly created position of Director of News, New Initiatives. She will oversee the expansion of Facebook's news partnerships and initiatives

title: (Untitled)
description: WhatsApp gives $1 million to researchers who will look into how misinformation spreads on the app

title: (Untitled)
description: Snapchat Vice President of content, Nick Bell, will leave the company

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook will work with French regulators on a pilot program in which the regulators will monitor the platform's content moderation practices

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook removes another 30 accounts on Facebook and 85 accounts on Instagram after "US law enforcement contacted U.S. about online activity that they recently discovered and which they believe may be linked to foreign entities." The FBI released a separate statement that "Americans should be aware that foreign actors—and Russia in particular—continue to try to influence public sentiment and voter perceptions through actions intended to sow discord"

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook publishes "An Independent Assessment of the Human Rights Impact of Facebook in Myanmar," which Facebook said concludes that the platform wasn't "doing enough to help prevent our platform from being used to foment division and incite offline violence"

title: (Untitled)
description: Snap Inc. will partner with Comscore to measure publishers' viewership in Discover

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook removes Trump campaign ad about immigration that many deemed to be racist, saying, "This ad violates Facebook's advertising policy against sensational content so we are rejecting it. While the video is allowed to be posted on Facebook, it cannot receive paid distribution"

title: (Untitled)
description: Gab returns online with the help of a new web host, Seattle-area web company, Epik. Despite facing backlash for its association with hateful posts, Gab emphasizes its commitment to free speech, while Epik's CEO asserts his support for free expression but acknowledges the need for content curation

title: (Untitled)
description: Apple News announces that it will replace its Midterm Elections section with an Election Night section on November 6 to provide real-time election results. Partners like the AP News will provide live results data and NBC News will provide live video

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter apologizes for "Kill all Jews" appearing as a trending topic on Twitter feeds in New York. Despite being in violation of the company's content policies, the topic was listed as trending for at least ten minutes

title: (Untitled)
description: The Intercept reports that Facebook allowed the publication to purchase an ad promoting content to users interested in the “white genocide conspiracy theory"

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter removes more than 10,000 automated accounts posing as Democrats and discouraging voters from participating in the midterms

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook is banning Proud Boys and its founder from Facebook and Instagram

title: (Untitled)
description: Vice News reporters were able to pose as Senators to pay for ads on Facebook, proving that there are significant issues with the platform's "paid for by" feature that is intended for transparency

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter issues a response to CNN after reporters found multiple threats made by Cesar Sayoc, alleged domestic terrorist, to media outlets and public officials. "We must do better and we will do better," the company wrote

title: (Untitled)
description: Tow Center releases a report, "The rumor caravan: From Twitter reply to disaster," that analyzes how a narrative emerged online falsely linking George Soros to Central American migrant caravans

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter launches a midterms events page, and BuzzFeed finds that it is already surfacing false news

title: (Untitled)
description: Gab temporarily goes offline after its host, GoDaddy, gave it 24 hours to find a different internet service provider, following the Pittsburgh synagogue shooting

title: (Untitled)
description: The New York Times reports on how Robert Bowers, the suspect in the Pittsburgh Synagogue shooting, "signed off" to his followers on Gab before the shooting. The incident underscores the challenges faced by social media platforms like Gab, which, although claiming to promote free speech, have become havens for extremism and hate speech. Gab's CEO, Andrew Torba, does not intend to make changes to the platform's content policies

title: (Untitled)
description: Following the Pittsburgh synagogue shooting, PayPal suspended service from Gab. Shortly after, payment processing site Stripe and cloud hosting company Joyent also announced that they would suspend services

title: (Untitled)
description: Google unveils Google Discover, a newsfeed on its mobile homepage that is a rebrand of Google Feed

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook hires BBC's Trushar Barot to oversee its Integrity Initiatives in India

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook removes another "82 Pages, Groups and accounts for coordinated inauthentic behavior that originated in Iran and targeted people in the U.S. and UK"

title: (Untitled)
description: WhatsApp adds stickers

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook to allow fact checking outlets to downrank stories with false headlines

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook has hired Former U.K. Deputy Prime Minister Nick Clegg to replace Elliot Schrage as Vice President of Communications and Global Affairs

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook launches a new blog series on its site called "The Hunt for False News" that will document the company's efforts to combat misinformation

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter suspends spambot accounts that spread pro-Saudi hashtags related to Jamal Khashoggi

title: (Untitled)
description: CNN investigation finds that 1,700 separate Facebook pages designed to look like they were run by local Women’s March organizers in the U.S. were actually run from Bangladesh in an effort to sell merchandise about American politics

title: (Untitled)
description: In an interview with NBC News, Reddit's CEO details the platforms midterm-related misinformation efforts, which includes, like Facebook, the creation of a "war room"

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter announces changes to how it handles reported Tweets in an effort to increase transparency. The platform will now display when an enforcement action was taken against a tweet and link to information about Twitter's content policy

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter releases onto its Elections Integrity Hub a trove of data containing "all the content associated with previously disclosed information operations" from places like Russia and Iran. It hopes that this data will spur "academic research and investigation"

title: (Untitled)
description: The New York Times covers Twitter's crackdown on more than 1,000 fake accounts trolling liberal activists, which were created as part of the NPC meme campaign. Twitter sprung into action as some of these accounts began to spread misinformation about the midterms

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook announces that accounts that illicitly scrape and re-publish content from other publishers will be demoted in its News Feed. The goal is to increase authenticity and promote higher quality content

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook allegedly knew about issues with how video metrics were measured long before the company disclosed the problem in 2016, according to a lawsuit filed by advertisers

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook will ban false information about the midterms, for example, about voting requirements

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook removes "559 Pages and 251 accounts" that demonstrated "coordinated inauthentic behavior" ahead of the midterm elections

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook deletes the account of Russian company Social Data Hub after the Hub said that it scraped and sold Facebook user data

title: (Untitled)
description: Snapchat introduces Snap Originals, which are original shows produced exclusively for the app

title: (Untitled)
description: Jessi Hempel leaves Wired to join LinkedIn as senior editor at large

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter announces that on October 23, Moments will be removed from mobile iOS and Android apps

title: (Untitled)
description: In the aftermath of the Pittsburgh synagogue shooting, Gab faces a decline in investors, with more than three dozen pulling out since the incident. Gab's crowdfunding page shows a decrease in investments, potentially impacting Gab's future fundraising efforts

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook releases Facebook Portal, a smart voice and video product designed to make video calls "more like hanging out"

title: (Untitled)
description: Apple releases a statement which disputes Bloomberg's report that Apple's servers contained "malicious chips"

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter's efforts to combat misinformation on the platform after 2016 made only a dent in malicious activity, a new report from the Knight Foundation finds

title: (Untitled)
description: Google launches a beta search tool for fact checking

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter updates "election integrity efforts," including expanding the criteria for taking down accounts and content

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook announces that Adam Mosseri, former head of News Feed, will be Instagram's new CEO

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter allows publishers to use In-Stream Video Ads on content across the globe. Previously, those ads could only be seen by local audiences

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook announces that more than 50 million user accounts were affected by a security attack

title: (Untitled)
description: Amazon, Apple, Google, and Twitter executives testify before Senate Commerce Committee on the subject of consumer data privacy

title: (Untitled)
description: BuzzFeed reports that Apple's Siri Suggested feature on Safari recommends fake and conspiracy news. Apple removed the examples of fake and misleading content provided to it by Buzzfeed

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter expands its "hateful conduct policy" to include "dehumanizing language"

title: (Untitled)
description: Instagram founders Kevin Systrom and Mike Krieger leave Facebook, reportedly over growing tensions with Facebook's CEO Mark Zuckerberg

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook has removed over a dozen hyperpartisan liberal and conservative pages for violating its policies against spamming. The pages were administered by the same fake account and were promoting content from LifeZette.com, a conservative website started by Fox News host Laura Ingraham

title: (Untitled)
description: A Tow Center report, "Data Journalism and the Law," urges lawmakers and platforms to ensure that data journalists are able to use public datasets without violating platform terms of service agreements

title: (Untitled)
description: Hoodline, a hyperlocal news site that has built a platform to ingest and analyse hundreds of terabytes of data to find and then write local news stories, raises $10 million in a Series A round to help take its effort nationwide

title: (Untitled)
description: Google announces an "open governance model" for its Accelerated Mobile Pages (AMP) Project, which will allow outside code contributions

title: (Untitled)
description: Gab announces an initial coin offering (ICO) with the intent of raising $10 million. As of the offering date, Gab had received commitments to raise $5.6 million

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter to begin placing live broadcasts on top of users' timelines

title: (Untitled)
description: YouTube will implement vertical video ads and will begin selling advertisers video ads based on "users' personalised home feeds"

title: (Untitled)
description: Google rolls out the Google News Initiative Cloud Program to support "local, small, and medium sized news organizations." The program will allow small newsrooms to apply for up to two years of free access to G Suite licenses

title: (Untitled)
description: A Tow Center report, "Bots and the future of automated accountability," discusses how social media bots can help with accountability journalism

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook-owned CrowdTangle to allow users to report false news by sending links to Facebook's misinformation team

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook gives brands more control over the types of content against which their ads will appear

title: (Untitled)
description: Apple is courting publications like the New York Times, the Washington Post and the Wall Street Journal to join its new subscription news app Texture

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter permanently bans Alex Jones and Infowars from the platform, saying, "We took this action based on new reports of Tweets and videos posted yesterday that violate our abusive behavior policy, in addition to the accounts’ previous violations"

title: (Untitled)
description: Apple hires Liz Schimel, former president of Condé Nast in China, as "head of news business"

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook COO Sheryl Sandberg and Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey testify during Senate Intelligence Committee hearing on how their platforms are used by foreign actors to influence elections. Google did not appear, but posted testimony online. Dorsey later appeared before the House Energy & Commerce Committee to answer questions about the Twitter algorithm

title: (Untitled)
description: Mark Zuckerberg writes an op-ed in the Washington Post about Facebook's role in protecting democracy from election interference by foreign actors

title: (Untitled)
description: The New York Times reports that Facebook's private groups are being used by "fringe" actors who are engaged in activity that appears to be against the platform's community guidelines. This includes an Infowars group, QAnon groups, regional chapters of the Proud Boys, and anti-vaccination groups

title: (Untitled)
description: In an interview with Bloomberg News, Trump follows up on his claims that Google is "rigged" against him and conservatives. He claims that Google, Facebook, and Amazon may be an "antitrust situation" but declines to comment on possible actions. The same day, Senator Orrin Hatch (R-UT) asked the FTC to look into Google search and advertising

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter will allow news organizations to apply to be exempt from a new Issue Ads Policy. The policy seeks to expand transparency around ads that are focused on a particular candidate or issue. This clearly stated position by Twitter is noteworthy considering Facebook faced backlash from news organizations this summer for not exempting news organizations from its political ad policies

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook's head of news products, Alex Hardiman, leaves to join The Atlantic as chief business and product officer. This is one of several high-level departures that occured in August, including Rachel Whetstone, a PR executive leaving for Netflix, and Dan Rose, who led businesses development. On the hiring front, Facebook brought on as chief marketing officer Antonio Lucio, formerly of HP

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook announces global rollout of Facebook Watch, a "video destination for episodic content." Facebook Watch was launched in 2017 and was previously only available in the U.S.

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter confirms that it is testing an "unfollow" feature

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitch helps drive Amazon's rising advertising business, but it also leaves the platform vulnerable to some of the safety, business and philosophical headaches that some of its rivals have faced for years

title: (Untitled)
description: In a series of tweets, Donald Trump claims that Google is biased against conservatives and intentionally suppresses conservative news outlets in its search results. Google responds with a statement that reads in part, "Search is not used to set a political agenda and we don't bias our results toward any political ideology"

title: (Untitled)
description: Data journalist Jonathan Albright discovers network of 9,000 conspiracy-related videos on YouTube

title: (Untitled)
description: A group of Facebook employees who call themselves "FB’ers for Political Diversity" claims the company culture is closed to those with views that are not left-leaning

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook is working with five publishers, including BuzzFeed, to test a tool that allows publishers to create four versions of a post so they can test performance and, by extension, increase reach

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook bans Myanmar Senior General Min Aung Hlaing, among others, saying in a statement, We want to prevent them from using our service to further inflame ethnic and religious tensions

title: (Untitled)
description: Google announces two new news efforts, one that creates scholarships to increase diversity in local newsrooms, and an "elections roadshow" to assist newsrooms in midterm reporting

title: (Untitled)
description: According to a Tow Center report, WhatsApp faces a significant fake news problem that is exacerbated by its end-to-end encryption. However, by utilizing metadata and implementing content moderation, WhatsApp could effectively combat the spread of misinformation without compromising encryption

title: (Untitled)
description: Representatives from Facebook, Twitter, and other tech companies will meet to discuss efforts to combat election meddling

title: (Untitled)
description: Google finds a misinformation effort across its products linked to Iran, and, specifically, to the Islamic Republic of Iran Broadcasting, a state-run media entity. This follows the news days earlier that Twitter suspended hundreds of accounts, many with Iran ties

title: (Untitled)
description: Apple buys the rights to a New York Times Magazine story about climate change and will create a TV series

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter says they have suspended 284 accounts, many from Iran, for "coordinated manipulation." On August 27th, the number is updated to 770

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook implements a reputational scoring system, rating users' trustworthiness on a scale of zero to one, as part of its efforts to combat fake news and identify malicious actors. This system analyzes various behavioral clues, such as users' interactions with content and their propensity to flag problematic posts, although the specifics of how it works are opaque

title: (Untitled)
description: Google releases a Google Trends Midterms page to show search trends ahead of the election

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook's publisher partnerships head Campbell Brown tells publishers that Mark Zuckerberg "doesn't care about publishers"

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter reverses course and suspends Alex Jones' permissions to tweet for one week, after Apple, YouTube, and Facebook all took measures against Jones and his content earlier in the month. Founder Jack Dorsey tells the Washington Post he is thinking of ways to change the platform to reduce hate speech, misinformation, and other issues

title: (Untitled)
description: Google rolls out an online library of U.S. political ads, which it promised lawmakers last year. It is also releasing a report detailing political ad-spending trends across its platforms

title: (Untitled)
description: Microsoft threatens to stop hosting services for Gab due to two anti-Semitic posts violating policy, demanding prompt action or suspension. If Gab is forced off Azure, it may face weeks/months of service disruption while securing a new provider, despite founder Andrew Torba's assertion that it's a violation of rights

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter founder Jack Dorsey gives an exclusive interview to Sean Hannity about his decision to keep Alex Jones on the platform, and the company's VP for trust and safety says Jones hasn't violated the platorm's rules

title: (Untitled)
description: Knight First Amendment Institute at Columbia University sent a letter to Facebook on behalf of researchers and journalists who cannot conduct their work due to the platform's terms of service. The institute calls for Facebook to amend its terms of service to establish a “safe harbor” for public-interest journalism and research focused on Facebook’s platform

title: (Untitled)
description: Apple, followed by Facebook and YouTube, remove Alex Jones from their platforms

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook announces that it will give $4.5 million to publishers to support local news. $3.5 million will be used to launch a 3-month membership pilot project, similar to the subscription pilot project, and $1 million will go to the NewsMatch campaign, which matches donations given to nonprofit newsrooms

title: (Untitled)
description: The popular Musical.ly app has been rebranded as TikTok

title: (Untitled)
description: The Intercept reports that, according to leaked documents, Google is planning to launch a version of its search engine in China that abides by state content censorship. The search engine, codenamed Dragonfly, will blacklist websites and search terms about human rights, democracy, religion, and peaceful protest

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook's Chief Security Officer, Alex Stamos, announces that he will leave the company. He intends to join Stanford University

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook announced that they removed "32 Pages and accounts from Facebook and Instagram because they were involved in coordinated inauthentic behavior" similar to what was seen ahead of the 2016 election. In a blog post, the company wrote: "We face determined, well-funded adversaries who will never give up and are constantly changing tactics. It’s an arms race and we need to constantly improve too"

title: (Untitled)
description: Google announces enhancements to its Data Search tool, aimed at promoting data journalism by simplifying the discovery of datasets. This includes increasing Google Search's ability to process tabular data. The goal is to make it easier for users to find relevant and reliable data across the web

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook removes four videos by InfoWars founder Alex Jones and suspends his profile, which only means that Jones can not post content for 30 days, but the pages remain up and other page administrators can do so

title: (Untitled)
description: Telegram is rolling out a new feature called Passport, which allows users to store and share real-world IDs and documents to use with services requiring such information. With end-to-end encryption and password protection, Telegram assures users that their data remains secure, though adoption will depend on companies integrating the feature

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook's stock fell 19 percent, or ~$120 billion, in one day after sluggish second quarter earnings. The company had anticipated lower earnings as a result of ramping up platform security

title: (Untitled)
description: YouTube deletes four videos by InfoWars founder Alex Jones and halts his ability to livestream for three months

title: (Untitled)
description: Snapchat will begin to allow non-exclusive shows on the platform

title: (Untitled)
description: WhatsApp moves to reduce the ability to quickly forward on the app in an effort to reduce the spread of misinformation, with specific limits for India, where users forward more than in any other country

title: (Untitled)
description: In a lengthy interview with Kara Swisher for Recode, Mark Zuckerberg explains the platform's content takedown policies by citing Holocaust deniers and saying "I don't believe that our platform should take that down because I think there are things that different people get wrong. I don't think that they're intentionally getting it wrong..."

title: (Untitled)
description: Snapchat will launch a news partnership initiative that will allow news orgs to better use the platform for newsgathering via Snapchats partners (NewsWhip, Storyful, SAM Desk, TagBoard)

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook says the company will more aggressively investigate suspected underage accounts on Facebook and Instagram following an investigation by Channel 4 in the U.K. on lax enforcement of the age 13 requirement

title: (Untitled)
description: Executives from Facebook, Google, and Twitter spoke to Congress about some lawmakers' concerns that the tech companies were biased against conservatives

title: (Untitled)
description: The Washington Post experiments with broadcasting on Twitch; its plans to include "postgame" coverage of major news events

title: (Untitled)
description: At a meeting held with publishers to share the latest on its efforts to combat misinformation, when asked why the InfoWars page is allowed to remain on the platform, Facebook's news feed head said the platform does not "take down false news"

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter will begin its effort to remove tens of millions of fake accounts from the platform

title: (Untitled)
description: YouTube announces a plan to surface "authoritative" news and expand news partnerships, including: a working group with news orgs to shape products and "tackle emerging challenges;" funding for newsrooms to build out video ops; expanding news partnerships team; showing article previews in search; expanding sections like Local, Top, and Breaking

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook shuts down tbh, an app the company had recently acquired, and two others because of "low usage"

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook hires CEO of Spiegel Online Jesper Doub as the director of news partnerships for Europe, the Middle East, and Africa, and will directly work with publishers and owners

title: (Untitled)
description: Tow Center: "There are a lot of rote tasks a good AI interviewer could do for you"

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook announces an Info and Ads section so anyone on the platform can see all the ads a page is actively running, and to see additional historical info about the page

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter launches its Ads Transparency Center and allowing user to see, for example, all the ads a given advertiser is running on the platform

title: (Untitled)
description: Google rebrands its advertising products as Google Ads (formerly Google AdWords), Google Marketing Platform (combines DoubleClick and Google Analytics 360 Suite), and Google Ad Manager (umbrella for DoubleClick for Publishers and DoubleClick Ad Exchange)

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook announces some updates to how the company is "investing in news subscriptions," including an expansion of Instant Articles subscriptions to Latin America, a new subscription button for publisher pages, the ability to give subscribers special offers, and insights into how likely a user is to become a subscriber, to name a few

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter will require new users to verify an email address or phone number

title: (Untitled)
description: Apple News announces a 2018 Midterm Elections section and emphasizes that "Reporting From Trusted Sources" is "Curated by Apple News Editors," which will also include "exclusive features" from publishers like Axios and Politico

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter acquires Smyte, a company that specializes in safety, spam, and security issues, with hopes it will help "to improve the health of the public conversation" on the platform

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook announces subscription groups for admins, and begins pilot tests with parenting and meal prep groups

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook is called out for flagging a Reveal story as political content, and then tweets, "To be clear – we flagged the ad, *not* the story – which is all over Facebook with many likes and shares"

title: (Untitled)
description: Medium, Twitter and Github take down a database of ICE employees off their platforms after an artist posted the scraped LinkedIn information

title: (Untitled)
description: Some Facebook Watch shows will use interactive features

title: (Untitled)
description: Tow Center report: "Friend and Foe: The Platform Press at the Heart of Journalism"

title: (Untitled)
description: Elliot Schrage, Facebook's head of public policy and communications, will step down from that role and become an advisor to Mark Zuckerberg and Sheryl Sandberg. Schrage became more vocal after the 2016 elections about the responsibilities of the company when it comes to misinformation and bad actors on the platform

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter begins sending users personalized news notifications

title: (Untitled)
description: Apple quietly updates its App Store Review Guidelines to limit how data is shared without consent

title: (Untitled)
description: The Senate Committee on the Judiciary and Senate Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation release Mark Zuckerberg's answers to questions asked during hearings as a result of the Cambridge Analytica scandal

title: (Untitled)
description: The Guardian spots a Facebook job listing for a "news credibility specialist" to help the platform combat fake news

title: (Untitled)
description: Instagram will soon allow for longer form video via a sort of video hub on the platform

title: (Untitled)
description: Snap announces its new publisher support team lead, a former Time Inc and Flipboard executive, Sarah Gallagher

title: (Untitled)
description: YouTube is hiring people from the news industry for a forthcoming news product

title: (Untitled)
description: Tow Center report: "Study: Apple News’s human editors prefer a few major newsrooms"

title: (Untitled)
description: Apple unveils several products and developments relevant to publishers at its annual Worldwide Developers Conference, including Apple News for Mac, and a browse tab for Apple News

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook CSO Alex Stamos tweets during Apple's Worldwide Developers Conference that Apple's user privacy features added to the updated browser, which were demoed using Facebook as an example, were "cute virtue signaling"

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter reorganizes its content partnerships team, which deals with publishers like BuzzFeed, among other organizational changes

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook publishes a blog post disputing the premise of a New York Times article that revealed that Facebook gave user data to phone device makers. (This is perhaps the first, or among the first, blog posts to dispute journalists' coverage of the company, though representatives from Facebook and other platforms have become increasingly vocal on Twitter about such matters)

title: (Untitled)
description: Apple plans to expand its digital advertising footstep via its apps

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook terminates its controversial Trending product (as well as its product Signal, a tool often used by journalists to find content across the platform)

title: (Untitled)
description: Papua New Guinea will temporarily shut down Facebook while officials study platform use and issues like the spread of misinformation

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook begins requiring election-related and "issue" ads to have a "paid for by" disclosure and for buyers to verify their identity. Issues include, for example, abortions and guns. Publishers are concerned that promoted posts about political subjects will be subject to the new requirements

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter will launch a website for small publishers to help them learn how to monetize on the platform

title: (Untitled)
description: Snap will launch a media accelerator

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter creates a special label for midterm candidates' user profiles

title: (Untitled)
description: Google will meet with publishers who have questions and concerns around the GDPR, including Google's decision to place upon publishers using Google ad products the responsibility of obtaining consent from users

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook Stories begins testing ads

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook will partner with think tank Atlantic Council, which will help the platform understand and anticipate "emerging threats and disinformation campaigns from around the world"

title: (Untitled)
description: Google releases YouTube Music, which will stream music like Spotify, and YouTube Premium, which will offer ad-free video

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook releases its first Community Standards Enforcement Report, which reveals, for example, that 583 million fake accounts were closed in Q1 of 2018 and 837 million pieces of spam

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook suspends 200 apps after an investigation into data misuse

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook will pay publishers between $1 million and $10 million for news shows for Watch

title: (Untitled)
description: Medium abruptly cancels the membership programs of its 21 remaining subscription publisher partners

title: (Untitled)
description: Google reveals its revamped Google News at the I/O conference. New features like Newscasts and Full Coverage will provide multiple news sources for a story, and in a range of formats

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook updates Live with features like Live Rewind for users and Live Crossposting for page managers

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook is considering an ad-free subscription plan for users

title: (Untitled)
description: Google announces that it will start requiring political ad buyers to provide identification information to prove U.S. citizenship or lawful residency, among other details

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook releases new metrics to allow page administrators to gain insights into video audience retention, including, for example, retention by followers vs. non-followers, and by gender

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook hired two external advisors (one to conduct an audit) in light of allegations regarding bias towards minority and conservative groups

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook ends its Free Basics internet initiative in several regions after criticism, including on its role in facilitating hate-speech. This service provided free internet access to users through the platform

title: (Untitled)
description: Mark Zuckerberg announces new "Clear History" feature at the F8 conference, which will allow users to erase their Facebook browsing data

title: (Untitled)
description: Iran bans Telegram after claiming the app encourages ‘armed uprisings’

title: (Untitled)
description: Tow Center: "The audience engagement industry struggles with measuring success"

title: (Untitled)
description: 9to5 reports on rumors that about Apple wanting to acquire Condé Nast. The publishing company's CEO Bob Sauerberg released a statement to the New York Post: “we are not for sale.” These rumors coincide with Apple's recent acquisition of the magazine subscription app Texture and plans to launch a premium news subscription product

title: (Untitled)
description: Chinese authorities admit they're able to retrieve deleted WeChat messages

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter is promoting more news links in your timeline

title: (Untitled)
description: WhatsApp founder and chief executive Jan Koum will step down from his role after disagreements with Facebook on encryption and user data policies

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter forms new partnerships with media companies like Disney and NBCUniversal that will produce exclusive shows for the platform

title: (Untitled)
description: Apple is pushing publishers to create longer videos for its News app after Apple created a Top Videos section to promote participating publishers. Apple is also placing ads in those videos and taking 50 percent of revenue

title: (Untitled)
description: Amazon renews NFL deal to stream Thursday night football games on the platform. The games will be available to its Prime subscribers and users on its gamer-focused service, Twitch

title: (Untitled)
description: LinkedIn CEO Jeff Weiner tells Axios that "arguably the most important" way LinkedIn stays ahead of fake news and platform abuse is "manual curation and the role of editors"

title: (Untitled)
description: Snapchat expands its partnership with Viacom, which will create new shows and produce Our Stories content for Snapchat

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook announces, in a blog post, that it will publish its internal enforcement guidelines to increase transparency and receive feedback. The social media platform is also developing a new feature that will allow users to request a re-review of content takedowns

title: (Untitled)
description: Flipboard introduces expanded tech coverage and private sharing features

title: (Untitled)
description: A CNN investigation finds that ads from "hundreds" of brands and organizations, including government agencies, appeared on YouTube channels "promoting white nationalists, Nazis, pedophilia, conspiracy theories and North Korean propaganda"

title: (Untitled)
description: BuzzFeed reporter Alex Kantrowitz tweets that there is "no sign" of the Ad Transparency Center, six months after Twitter announced that it would launch "in the coming weeks." Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey responds by tweeting: "Was definitely a mistake for us to say 'in the coming weeks.' Our fault. It’s at least months of work, and we are aiming to launch by summer. Important for us to get this right"

title: (Untitled)
description: Tow Center report: "WeChatting American Politics: Misinformation, Polarization, and Immigrant Chinese Media"

title: (Untitled)
description: Tow Center: "Facebook struggles to promote ‘meaningful interactions’ for local publishers, data shows"

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook says it is "likely" to roll out new buttons that will allow users to vote comments up or down

title: (Untitled)
description: Snapchat's new Shoppable AR lets advertisers link websites to sponsored photo filters. Users will be able to buy products directly within Snapchat

title: (Untitled)
description: In a blog post, Facebook announces that its updated "terms and data policy" will rollout to everyone on the platform, not just those in the EU. These changes include allowing users to set data sharing and face recognition preferences as well as improving platform protection for teen users

title: (Untitled)
description: Apple will launch a subscription service within the next year by integrating the technology of its previously acquired magazine subscription app, Texture, into its current news product, Apple News. The participating magazine publishers will receive a portion of the service's revenue

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook partners with Boom, a fact-checking firm in India, to "review English-language news stories shared on the platform that are flagged by users, check facts, and rate their accuracy." This pilot test will only run in India, Facebook's largest market, coinciding with the upcoming state elections in Karnataka, India

title: (Untitled)
description: Tow Center: "Next time you visit, please bring fiber’: Unheralded moments from the Zuck hearings"

title: (Untitled)
description: Snapchat is testing a commerce function with some Discover partners

title: (Untitled)
description: Mark Zuckerberg appears before Congress for two days of testimony as fallout from the Cambridge Analytica scandal continues. He answered questions on topics ranging from the GDPR to "fake news"

title: (Untitled)
description: Reddit finds nearly 1,000 accounts potentially linked to Russia's IRA

title: (Untitled)
description: Tow Center: "Why a suit and tie won't save Zuckerberg"

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook partners with various foundations to launch a new initiative that will facilitate independent academic research on the impact of social media on democracy, focusing primarily on elections

title: (Untitled)
description: Snapchat brings back chronological Stories feed for some

title: (Untitled)
description: TechCrunch reports that sources told them that Facebook deleted messages sent to them by Mark Zuckerberg from their inbox. Facebook responded to TechCrunch's inquiry in a statement claiming that it took these measures to "protect our executives’ communications" and that they were done in "full compliance with our legal obligations to preserve messages"

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook acknowledges delay in detecting foreign interference on its site and announces plans to increase transparency on the platform. Moving forward, it will require all advertisers to provide information about their identity and location before allowing them to promote "issue ads." Issue ads, as described in the blog post, consist of ads that contain communications on "political topics that are being debated across the country." The company will also label these ads as "Political Ad" and provide users with information on who's funding the ad

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter removes more than 1.2 million terrorism-promoting accounts on the platform, of which 274,000 were removed during the second half of 2017

title: (Untitled)
description: Rumble announces a $20 million investment in its global video creator community. The company reports that its community doubled in size in the previous year and its video inventory has grown to over one million assets. At the NAB Show, CEO Chris Pavlovski will discuss the impact of blockchain technology on video and participate in a TV innovation panel

title: (Untitled)
description: In the first audit conducted by the Media Rating Council, Facebook and Instagram receive accreditation on how they report ad impressions in the News Feed. Two additional ad audits are forthcoming

title: (Untitled)
description: Australia plans to investigate Facebook for possible violation of privacy laws after the company revealed that approximately 300,000 users, out of the 87 million whose data Cambridge Analytica obtained, were in Australia. Authorities in Indonesia also announced their plans to initiate an investigation into the company's compliance with the country's privacy laws

title: (Untitled)
description: Cambridge Analytica releases a statement refuting a Facebook report that the company "improperly" obtained the data of 87 million Facebook users. Cambridge Analytica admits to licensing data on 30 million users from Global Science Research, and claims that the data was not used to influence 2016 election outcomes

title: (Untitled)
description: Tow Center report: "The partnership press: Lessons for platform-publisher collaborations as Facebook and news outlets team to fight misinformation"

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook updates the News Feed with features that help users better identify trustworthy sources. The feature, which was in testing last year and will now be released in the U.S., shows users other articles by the same publisher and allows users to see friends who shared that article

title: (Untitled)
description: A Facebook white paper published shortly after the 2016 election highlights that "Trump’s FB campaigns were more complex than Clinton’s and better leveraged Facebook’s ability to optimize for outcomes"

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook updates its Messenger capabilities to support 360 photos and HD videos. The photos can be taken directly from the app while the videos can only be shared through the app

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook reports that it has deleted more than 100 Facebook and Instagram accounts, as well as 138 Facebook pages, that were run by Russia's Internet Research Agency. Facebook's Chief Security Officer Alex Stamos, who published the blog post about the decision, noted the IRA's efforts to manipulate user experience on the platform while stating that "Facebook was built for conversation and human connection"

title: (Untitled)
description: Snapchat launches a new video chat feature that will enable users to communicate in groups of up to 16 people

title: (Untitled)
description: During an interview on Vox's The Ezra Klein Show, Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg discusses the company's future and its efforts to become more transparent and reliable. While commenting on the company's future, Zuckerberg says: “I wish I could solve all these issues in three months or six months, but I just think the reality is that solving some of these questions is just going to take a longer period of time”

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook plans to build a Custom Audiences certification tool that will require marketers to provide proof of having rightfully obtained users' consent to use data

title: (Untitled)
description: Conservative publishers criticize Facebook's algorithm change by claiming that Facebook "unfairly targeted their traffic," POLITICO reports. The social media platform announced its news feed algorithm change in January, with the aim to promote content from users' friends and family and reduce content from public pages

title: (Untitled)
description: In a leaked internal memo from 2016, Facebook Vice President Andrew "Boz" Bosworth writes about the company's priority of connecting people, even if there are sometimes negative externalities such as terrorist attacks coordinated on its tools

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook starts fact-checking photos and videos on the platform, in addition to the news articles it previously fact-checked. In a blog post about this, Facebook reiterates plans to limit foreign interference, block fake accounts and reduce the spread of false information on the platform

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook puts a halt to its app review process to audit its platform after privacy scandal involving Cambridge Analytica. During that time, developers will not be able to launch apps or chatbots on the platform

title: (Untitled)
description: Digital media company behind Cooking Panda and Opposing Views, Render Media, shuts down following Facebook's changes to its branded content guidelines and changes to the News Feed algorithm to deprioritize certain types of news

title: (Untitled)
description: In light of the Cambridge Analytica revelations, Facebook announces its plans to make data settings easier to find. These changes will include a new settings menu design, a privacy shortcut menu and tools to manage data. Facebook also shuts down Partner Categories, which will reduce the data used on the site (including third-party data) in ad targeting

title: (Untitled)
description: Mark Zuckerberg decides to testify before Congress after backlash from the Cambridge Analytica scandal

title: (Untitled)
description: Apple will allow publishers using Google's ad product DoubleClick for Publishers to serve those ads in Apple News

title: (Untitled)
description: Tumblr releases list of 84 usernames it believes engaged in "state-sponsored disinformation and propaganda campaigns"

title: (Untitled)
description: Google's Jigsaw releases Outline, an open source project that “provides a safer way for news organizations and journalists to access the internet”

title: (Untitled)
description: Tow Center report: "Managing a 21st-century newsroom workforce: A case study of NYC news media"

title: (Untitled)
description: Instagram will now show more timely posts and introduce a "New Posts" button so that the feed doesn't auto-refresh as users scroll

title: (Untitled)
description: Google announces the Google News Initiative, a $300 million commitment to formalize its efforts with publishers, which include prioritizing surfacing fact-checked and quality content for its users and contributing to efforts to increase media literacy. As part of the initiative, Google expanded access to its product Subscribe with Google, which allows users to subscribe to and access subscription content using their Google account

title: (Untitled)
description: YouTube removes an Atlantic video of alt-right leader Richard Spencer's speech from search results, but restored it after pushback from the Atlantic. The editor in chief said that there is a "difference between videos made by Nazis and videos about Nazis"

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook’s Chief Information Security Officer, Alex Stamos, resigns after internal disagreements over how much information the company should disclose about disinformation on its site

title: (Untitled)
description: Data leak involving political data firm Cambridge Analytica and Facebook surfaces a year after the election. Under the pretense of collecting data for academic purposes, Facebook reports, a contractor to the British firm obtained user data from more than 50 million Facebook profiles that would later be used to target users and potentially influence political outcomes during the 2016 election. Facebook has hired a forensics firm to investigate Cambridge Analytica and Mark Zuckerberg has issued a statement with a timeline of the events, "including details on Facebook’s plan to investigate the breach. Zuckerberg has also apologized during an interview with Recode and in multiple U.K. and U.S. newspaper ads. Following a CNN interview where Zuckerberg stated that he would be "happy" to testify, bipartisan leaders of several House and Senate committees requested that he testifies

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook is expanding Facebook Lite to the U.S and other developed countries. This barebone version of the social media platform was designed to reach users with less compatible phones and data services and was originally rolled out in a handful of countries, including Vietnam and Bangladesh

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook issues an apology after users report child abuse search suggestions

title: (Untitled)
description: Tow Center report: "Study: VR for news prompts empathy, but only with the right mix of factors"

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook publishes a blog post explaining why it has banned Britain First and its leaders' Facebook pages

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter develops curated news timelines to deliver content during breaking news events, which it will promote via a module at the top of the home timeline

title: (Untitled)
description: Google releases a report detailing its progress on taking down deceptive content on its platforms. The firm reports removing "3.2B ‘bad ads’ and blocked 320K publishers, 90K sites, 700K mobile apps"

title: (Untitled)
description: Google plans to change the way paying news subscribers access stories, in an effort to support media companies. Specifically, users will see stories from publications to which they subscribe toward the top of search results. The company will make an official announcement on March 20

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook to launch a news section that caters strictly to national news on its Watch platform

title: (Untitled)
description: After receiving criticisms for hosting extremist content on the site, YouTube CEO Susan Wojcicki speaks on the company's plans to add "information cues" to conspiracy-related videos, during a panel at the South by Southwest Interactive festival. When there is a conspiracy video, the information cue will appear below the video with a link to Wikipedia for more information

title: (Untitled)
description: YouTube caps the amount of time contracted moderators can spend reviewing disturbing content at four hours per day

title: (Untitled)
description: Apple purchases digital magazine app Texture

title: (Untitled)
description: Google announces plans to push for the standardization of the AMP framework for non-AMP web content

title: (Untitled)
description: The Associated Press will work in partnership with Facebook to leverage their fact-checking capabilities during the U.S. midterm election

title: (Untitled)
description: Tow Center: "The new ‘billion-dollar problem’ for platforms and publishers"

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook announces a pilot feature that will enable publishers to label articles and live videos as Breaking News

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook is working on fact-checking protocols for satirical news pieces after satirical website The Babylon Bee protested Facebook for disputing their story

title: (Untitled)
description: Reddit CEO announces that the company is investigating Russian propaganda on the site

title: (Untitled)
description: Chinese social media platform WeChat reaches 1 billion accounts worldwide

title: (Untitled)
description: Snapchat becomes increasingly flexible about advertising agreements and ad placements on its platform

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook reports having found little evidence of Russian involvement in Brexit referendum, after the House of Commons committee requested that the firm investigate Russian ad spend during the period leading up to the referendum

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey tweets to announce Twitter's commitment to helping "increase the collective health, openness, and civility of public conversation, and to hold ourselves publicly accountable towards progress"

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook ends Explore Feed pilot in response to user feedback reporting that they did not want multiple news feeds

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter introduces Bookmarks feature to allow users to save tweets

title: (Untitled)
description: Feel-good publisher LittleThings shuts down following Facebook's algorithm change in January to deprioritize news in the News Feed

title: (Untitled)
description: Obama speaks at an MIT conference about Google, Facebook and Twitter's influence on American culture and the need for "business models that recognizes they are a public good as well as a commercial enterprise"

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook announces three-month pilot program, Local News Subscriptions Accelerator, to help publishers improve their digital subscriptions business

title: (Untitled)
description: Data journalist Jonathan Albright discovers network of 9,000 conspiracy-related videos on YouTube

title: (Untitled)
description: Tow Center: "RIP Facebook Live: As subsidies end, so does publisher participation"

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook removes redundant and outdated reporting metrics and introduces metric labels to simplify ad measurement

title: (Untitled)
description: Snapchat plans to double the number of its video shows, and will do so in part by approaching more digital and legacy publishers

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook Journalism Project to launch journalist training program in partnership with Society of Professional Journalists. The training will focus on Facebook's own tools and products

title: (Untitled)
description: White nationalist Jared Taylor and his organization, American Renaissance, sue Twitter for banning their accounts

title: (Untitled)
description: Pavel Durov, CEO of Telegram, secures $850 million in a presale of the company's cryptocurrency from accredited investors. Now, a second private presale aims for a similar amount, totaling over $1.6 billion before the ICO goes public. Concerns remain regarding Telegram's ambitious plans for its Telegram Open Network (TON), with critics questioning technical details and the value proposition

title: (Untitled)
description: Google will no longer support the meta news keyword tag in Google News. The feature was previously introduced to help news publishers classify their stories but was only adopted by 5% of publishers

title: (Untitled)
description: Vice President of Facebook Ads, Rob Goldman, apologizes to Facebook and special counsel Robert Mueller after tweeting his personal views on the recent indictment of 13 Russians for their involvement in the Trump campaign, and the use of Facebook in that effort

title: (Untitled)
description: Donald Trump responds to Vice President of Facebook Ads' tweet, in which he reports that "the majority of Russian Ad spend happened AFTER the election"

title: (Untitled)
description: Snapchat will give analytics to creators, likely in an effort to prevent them from moving to competing platforms like Instagram

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter launches new initiative to partner with local news stations to air live footage during breaking news events

title: (Untitled)
description: Google releases to all publishers its AMP stories, which is similar to Snapchat stories

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook to release a new design of Page Insights that will "deliver page posts’ organic reach using the same methodology as it has for promoted posts"

title: (Untitled)
description: At the Code Media conference, Facebook's head of news partnerships says, "If you're a publisher who feels Facebook isn't good for your business, you shouldn't be on Facebook," adding, "News organizations should be thinking differently about their relationship with Facebook. This is not U.S. stepping back from news, this is U.S. changing our relationship with publishers. This is about Facebook doing something it's never done before, having a point of view and leaning into quality news"

title: (Untitled)
description: Also at the Code Media conference, Facebook announces it will add a news section to Watch that could be useful in breaking news, and that it had resolved issues with Apple that prevented Facebook from rolling out subscriptions for publishers in its app on iOS devices

title: (Untitled)
description: Snapchat is offering free ad credits to advertisers to pull them away from Instagram

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter reports Q4 2017 earnings and is profitable for the first time since launch

title: (Untitled)
description: Telegram is expanding its platform with a new web login widget, enabling businesses to connect with users directly through their websites via Telegram bots. This move aligns with Telegram's broader plans, including the integration of payments, as part of its ambitious ICO project, aiming to enhance user engagement and functionality

title: (Untitled)
description: Snapchat says that Discover partners earned $100 million in revenue in 2017

title: (Untitled)
description: Apple removed the secure messaging app Telegram from the App Store due to the discovery of child pornography being distributed on the app. Telegram's history of similar issues, including concerns about terrorism-related content, has led to criticism and actions by governments to address the misuse of its platform

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook wants Watch to rival YouTube by expanding access to more creators and potentially pursuing ad revenue share with some creators instead of paying directly for content

title: (Untitled)
description: Tow Center: "More than half of Facebook Instant Articles partners may have abandoned it"

title: (Untitled)
description: Amazon's "other revenue," which is mostly advertising, grew more than 60 percent year-over-year in the last quarter of 2017

title: (Untitled)
description: The number of daily active users on Facebook fell for the first time in the U.S. and Canada

title: (Untitled)
description: Google brings back Featured Snippets at the top of search results, which had been criticized for surfacing false information from unreliable sources, and statements like "women are evil"

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook announces that the News Feed will "prioritize local news"

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook announces the Facebook Journalism Project Scholarship for students

title: (Untitled)
description: Google begins testing a hyperlocal news app called Bulletin to which any user can contribute

title: (Untitled)
description: Google will allow users to mute certain ads - for example, the reminder ads that show a product that a user had been searching for on another site

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter will allow for advertiser sponsored Moments

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter is working on a video sharing feature that is similar to Snapchat

title: (Untitled)
description: Snapchat will allow users to share public Stories outside of the app, across the web

title: (Untitled)
