description: Facebook will allow users to rate which news sites they find "trustworthy," and those entities will be prioritized in the News Feed

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter will contact the 677,775 users who interacted with accounts with potential connections to Russia, according to a company blog post providing updates about the company's investigation into Russia-related election meddling

title: (Untitled)
description: Snap laid off two dozen employees that were on a publisher partnerships team

title: (Untitled)
description: Snapchat will host a publisher summit, and sent a note to publishers doubling down on the relationship

title: (Untitled)
description: Google announces that, beginning in July 2018, faster pages will rank (and surface) higher in mobile search

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter's director of public policy tells senators that the company is “working to identify and inform individually the users who have been exposed to IRA accounts during the election"

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook updates the News Feed to prioritize user content over publishers', which is expected to result in a significantly smaller audience and less revenue for publishers

title: (Untitled)
description: Tow Center: "How WeChat became the primary news source in China"

title: (Untitled)
description: Tow Center: "WeChat reaches audiences conventional media in China cannot"

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook tests a feature called Today In that will highlight local news and events

title: (Untitled)
description: In response to controversy after a famous YouTube creator decided to post a video of a person who had committed suicide, YouTube's account on Twitter writes an open letter that read, "We know that the actions of one creator can affect the entire community, so we'll have more to share soon on steps we’re taking to ensure a video like this is never circulated again"

title: (Untitled)
description: Google will remove the "google.com/amp" from AMP post URLs, at the end of which a publisher's URL was attached. Posts now appear under a publisher's URL

title: (Untitled)
description: Telegram plans to launch the "Telegram Open Network," a blockchain platform with native cryptocurrency. It will be funded through an Initial Coin Offering (ICO)

title: (Untitled)
description: The Internet Association, which includes companies like Google and Facebook, will fight against the FCC's repeal of net neutrality

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter publishes a post called "World Leaders on Twitter" (likely in response to pressure to delete Trump's account, but broad in scope) that reads: "Blocking a world leader from Twitter or removing their controversial Tweets would hide important information people should be able to see and debate"

title: (Untitled)
description: Mark Zuckerberg writes a blog post announcing that his "personal challenge" for 2018 will be to fix issues with Facebook, "whether it's protecting our community from abuse and hate, defending against interference by nation states, or making sure that time spent on Facebook is time well spent." He also wants to make sure that the platform is "a decentralizing force that puts more power in people's hands"

title: (Untitled)
description: Telegram blocks channel promoting violence against Iran's government

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook is testing a feature that would allow brands to send mass messages on Messenger

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook and Universal Music agree to a music licensing deal that will allow users to upload videos with licensed music. Two weeks later, YouTube announces it will release a music subscription service

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook wants to change licensing terms for Watch shows in ways that would limit monetization opportunities for publishers

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook will show Related Articles instead of a Disputed Flag next to stories flagged as false

title: (Untitled)
description: Germany's Federal Cartel Office finds that, as a result of its market dominance, Facebook leaves users with little choice but to accept their questionable data collection practices

title: (Untitled)
description: Publishers will have to pay to participate in the Coalition for Better Ads' Better Ads Experience Program (of which Google is a founding member), in which they pledge not to run "annoying ads." Participating and non-participating publishers will face potential site take-down if they do so

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook will fight "engagement bait" in the News Feed

title: (Untitled)
description: Google will no longer allow sites that don't disclose their country of origin to appear in Google News

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter pauses account verification, tweeting: "Verification was meant to authenticate identity & voice but it is interpreted as an endorsement or an indicator of importance. We recognize that we have created this confusion and need to resolve it"

title: (Untitled)
description: Apple releases a new feature in iTunes called Podcast Analytics for podcast creators and advertisers

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook will allow pre-roll ads for Watch videos

description: Instagram tests a standalone messaging app in Turkey, Uruguay, Chile, Portugal, Italy and Israel

title: (Untitled)

title: (Untitled)

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook introduces an app called Messenger Kids

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter expands availability of Twitter Lite, which uses less data, to 24 additional countries

title: (Untitled)
description: Snapchat starts algorithm-personalized redesign splitting social and media

title: (Untitled)
description: YouTube begins testing a feature called Reels, which is similar to Stories on Facebook and Snapchat

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook will allow some publishers to label some stories as "breaking"

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook and Twitter will cooperate with U.K. officials investigating potential Russian involvement with Brexit vote

title: (Untitled)
description: Instagram is quietly testing new features including a regram button and GIF search, among others

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook teams up with Toronto's Ryerson School of Journalism for a "digital news innovation challenge" to combat misinformation

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook's VP of ad products wrote a blog post called "Our Advertising Principles," which tells users that the platform doesn't sell "personal information" like name, phone number, or email address, and tells users how they can "control" the ads they're shown

title: (Untitled)
description: David Karp, who founded blogging site Tumblr, plans to step down as CEO after more than a decade

title: (Untitled)
description: Snapchat releases Promoted Stories for advertisers

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook will create a portal so users can see if they liked any accounts on FB or Instagram linked to Russia's Internet Research Agency

title: (Untitled)

title: (Untitled)

title: (Untitled)

title: (Untitled)
description: Tow Center: "The ‘fake news’ focus shifts to YouTube"

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter updates its system for reviewing reports of abusive, violent, or hateful content, and also updates rules so that handles, bios, and user and header photos are taken into consideration, as well as affiliation with organizations (even off platform) that promote violence

title: (Untitled)
description: Instagram begins testing a feature to allow users to follow hashtags

title: (Untitled)
description: During a call about the company's quarterly earnings report, which was disappointing, Evan Spiegel says Snapchat would start to pay creators on the platform, and that the app will be redesigned to become easier to use

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter expands character limit for tweets to 280

title: (Untitled)
description: Google will start to show more information about publishers in search results so users can "understand the tone, expertise and history of the publisher"

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook adds a "Monetization Tab" to Instant Articles to allow publishers to easily turn on or off Recirculation Ads, which appear at the bottom of the articles

title: (Untitled)
description: On the heels of U.S. congressional hearings with Facebook, Google, and Twitter regarding Russia and the U.S. election, U.K. lawmakers asked Twitter to give them a list of accounts linked to the Russian government backed Internet Research Agency

title: (Untitled)
description: The House Intelligence Committee released some of the ads linked to Russia and purchased on Facebook before the election

title: (Untitled)
description: Tow Center: "Social platforms grilled on Russia"

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook's quarterly earnings report came out at the same time as the congressional hearings, showing growth. Mark Zuckerberg said in a statement to investors, "We're serious about preventing abuse on our platforms. We're investing so much in security that it will impact our profitability," adding, "Protecting our community is more important than maximizing our profits"

title: (Untitled)
description: Tow Center: "How misinformation spreads on WeChat"

title: (Untitled)
description: Google announces, "We have found some evidence of efforts to misuse our platforms during the 2016 U.S. election by actors linked to the Internet Research Agency in Russia." The company plans to create a public database of its ads and to require political advertisers to be based in the U.S.

title: (Untitled)
description: Recode reported on early testimony from Facebook, Google, and Twitter in preparation for Congressional hearings later in the week. Facebook planned to reveal that 126 million Facebook users may have seen Russian-government backed content, and that some of that content was also on Instagram; Google would discuss results from an internal investigation that found "evidence of efforts to misuse our platforms during the 2016 U.S. election by actors linked to the Internet Research Agency in Russia," and Twitter would reveal that 2,700 accounts on its own platform were linked to that agency

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter will label political ads on its platform, and increase transparency around the ads on the platform and who paid for them

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter said that it overcounted monthly user numbers for three years

description: Tow Center: "Local audiences consuming news on social platforms are hungry for transparency"

description: Tow Center: "The ad industry is changing—here’s what publishers can expect"

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook is testing a new product called Sets that is similar to Pinterest's boards

title: (Untitled)
description: Head of Facebook Messenger says that Facebook should "overthink" its future ad products to prevent the type of election meddling that happened in 2016

title: (Untitled)
description: Bloomberg reports that Facebook and Google directly helped Secure America Now's efforts to target anti-refugee ads in swing states leading up to the 2016 election

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter releases new video-centric ad format called Video Website Card

title: (Untitled)
description: The New York Times reports that Google allows ads containing fake news to appear even on fact-checking sites

title: (Untitled)
description: After founder Jack Dorsey takes to Twitter to emphasize plans to combat hate and harassment on the platform, the Trust & Safety Council sent an email to members with new rules

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook is experimenting with allowing brands to study users' posts and comments to inform their marketing strategies

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook acquires the app tbh in an effort to reach younger audiences

title: (Untitled)
description: Snapchat strikes a deal with NBCUniversal to form a joint venture that will develop and produce new shows for Snapchat

title: (Untitled)

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook Stories is opening up to Pages, allowing brands, news publishers, athletes, entertainers and nonprofits to post to the feature

title: (Untitled)

title: (Untitled)
description: A Facebook executive told fact checking partners that its fake news tag reduces the spread of such posts by 80 percent

title: (Untitled)
description: The House Intelligence Committee will release Facebook ads linked to Russia

title: (Untitled)
description: Medium announces that anyone who publishes on Medium can paywall their content

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter to release a bookmarking tool to allow for saving tweets to read later

title: (Untitled)
description: Russian operatives bought ads across several of Google's services without the company's knowledge

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook sent out an email assuring advertisers that there will be increased "human review" of ads targeted on the platform

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook will team up with conservative magazine The Weekly Standard as a fact-checking partner

title: (Untitled)
description: Facebook will roll out a button in the News Feed that will allow readers to find additional information and context for stories they read; the product was developed as part of the Facebook Journalism Project

title: (Untitled)
description: Tow Center: "Publishers shift focus from Facebook? Not so fast"

title: (Untitled)
description: In response to conspiracy videos about the Las Vegas shooting, YouTube has updated its algorithm to in favor of reputable news sources

title: (Untitled)
description: Google is paying publishers to use a forthcoming product called Stamp, which will compete with Snapchat Discover and Instagram Stories

description: CNN reports that Russian ads on Facebook targeted two states significant to Donald Trump's victory - Wisconsin and Michigan

description: Instagram Stories can now be cross-posted as Facebook Stories, but not the other way around (yet)

description: Vox properties The Verge and Polygon announce forthcoming weekly live Twitter shows

description: Instagram Stories adds an interactive poll sticker that allows users to ask questions of their followers

title: (Untitled)
description: The New York Times reports the names of pages found to have been linked to Russia, including Secured Borders, LGBT United, and Defend the 2nd. Facebook found hundreds of such pages, but hasn't publicly released the names

title: (Untitled)
description: Apple News is working with Google and select publishers on a trial that allows them to place ads into their Apple News pages using Google's DoubleClick ad program, which many publishers use to place ads elsewhere

title: (Untitled)
description: Following an event at the UN the previous week during which world leaders said that social platforms need to do more to curb terrorist activity on their platforms, the European Commission proposed new guidelines for platforms to step up their efforts in the coming months

description: Twitter publishes "Update: Russian Interference in 2016 U.S. Election, Bots, & Misinformation," a roundup of findings related to their investigation of how their platform was misused, and preventative measures and changes the platform will take in light of these revelations

description: The New York Times, Wall Street Journal, and Financial Times will take a "wait-and-see" approach to Facebook's recently launched subscription program, while other publications like the Washington Post are embracing the feature

description: The Daily Beast reports that a Facebook account tied to Russia called United Muslims of America bought election-related ads

description: Google, Facebook, and Twitter have been invited to testify before the Senate Intelligence Committee regarding election-related Russian activity on their platforms

title: (Untitled)
description: Mark Zuckerberg responds to Trump's tweets suggesting that Facebook is against him, writing: "Trump says Facebook is against him. Liberals say we helped Trump. Both sides are upset about ideas and content they don't like. That's what running a platform for all ideas looks like"

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter will meet with the Senate Intelligence Committee regarding election interference by Russia and about bots and misinformation on the platform

title: (Untitled)
description: Google removes support for YouTube videos from Amazon's Echo Show, seen as a competitive move

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter doubles character limit for tweets to 280

description: Instagram rolls out a Comment Controls feature for accounts to prevent against trolling

description: Tow Center: "What iOS 11 means for news publishers and readers"

title: (Untitled)
description: The Washington Post reports that, just after the election, Barack Obama spoke with Mark Zuckerberg about the importance of addressing political misinformation on the platform

title: (Untitled)
description: British Prime Minister Theresa May calls on technology firms to radically increase the speed with which they remove terrorist content after a series of terrorist attacks in the U.K. carried out by individuals who were radicalized online

title: (Untitled)
description: Mark Zuckerberg posts a Facebook Live video about steps the company will take to prevent election meddling, such as increased transparency around ad buys, and says the company will give Congress the ads purchased on the platforms by Russians before the election

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter will meet with the Senate Intelligence Committee regarding election interference by Russia, and about bots and misinformation on the platform

title: (Untitled)
description: Sheryl Sandberg writes a Facebook post in response to ProPublica's discovery that ads on the platform can be targeted to, for example, a "Jew-hater." As a result, Facebook will restrict the types of ad targeting that can take place, will add more human oversight of the ad targeting process, and will encourage users to report abuse

title: (Untitled)
description: Twitter releases its 11th biannual Transparency Report, which includes more transparency around how the company handles government terms of service requests and content takedown requests, among other changes

title: (Untitled)
description: In response to government pressure, Google and Facebook are set to announce campaigns to educate Canadians about misinformation, and Facebook will launch the Canadian Election Integrity Initiative

title: (Untitled)
description: The Daily Beast reports on activists' complaints that Facebook has been removing posts about ethnic cleansing involving the Rohingya people in Burma

title: (Untitled)
description: Snapchat removed Al Jazeera from Discover in Saudi Arabia after a request from the Saudi Arabian government

title: (Untitled)
description: In response to a Daily Beast article that found ads can be targeted to racist users, Twitter says it fixed a bug that allowed such campaigns

description: Facebook gave copies of ads purchased by Russians, as well as additional additional information, to Robert Mueller as part of his investigation into Russia's influence in the election

description: Google introduces Community Updates, a redesign of Google News with a Local tab that will provide search results from local news sources

description: The Spanish Data Protection Agency fines Facebook 1.2 million euros for violating user privacy

description: Facebook is willing to spend up to $1 billion on original video content

description: Instagram is testing cross-posting Stories to Facebook

description: Three weeks after its initial launch, BitChute's founder Ray Vahey discusses the platform's peer-to-peer technology with Torrent Freak. Vahey founded the platform as an alternative to "increased levels of censorship by the large social media platforms." Using WebTorrent technology, Bitchute distributes video hosting among users, aiming to allow users freedom to create and monetize video content that may be restricted by platforms such as YouTube. BitChute's claims to be a decentralized platform were later disputed by figures such as Fredrick Brennan, founder and former of 8chan
